Make your voice heard about the issues you care about.\\r\\n\",\"page_title\":\"Entitlement Reform Legislation - Vote on Bills, Stay informed, Hold Your Reps Accountable\",\"icons\":{\"black\":\"https://assets.causes.com/issue/icon/entitlement-reform/black_entitlement-reform-1429042066.svg\",\"grey\":\"https://assets.causes.com/issue/icon/entitlement-reform/grey_entitlement-reform-1429042066.svg\",\"white\":\"https://assets.causes.com/issue/icon/entitlement-reform/white_entitlement-reform-1429042066.svg\"},\"cover_image_url\":null,\"is_following\":false}],\"articles\":[{\"title\":\"COVID-19 Pandemic Presents Income Challenges for Older Americans\",\"id\":45493,\"slug\":\"45493-covid-19-pandemic-presents-income-challenges-older-americans\",\"links\":{\"self\":\"https://www.causes.com/articles/45493-covid-19-pandemic-presents-income-challenges-older-americans\",\"article_comments\":\"/api/articles/45493-covid-19-pandemic-presents-income-challenges-older-americans/comments\",\"signatures\":\"/api/v3/articles/45493/signatures?include=user\"},\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis content leverages data from USAFacts, a non-profit that visualizes governmental data. You can learn more on its\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003ewebsite\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e,\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eFacebook\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e, and\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eTwitter\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003chr\u003e\u003ch3\u003eWhat’s the story?\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eThe income sources relied upon by older Americans, particularly those who are considering or are already in retirement, are different than their younger counterparts. As a result, the older Americans may feel the economic impact of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic differently.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eHow many older Americans are there \u0026amp; where does their income come from?\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eAccording to data from the Census Bureau, as of 2018 there were 72.7 million Americans over the age of 60 and representing 22% of the U.S. population. For the last decade, 10,000 Americans have turned 65 which is a common retirement age.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eIn 2019, the Social Security Administration (SSA) gave Old-Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance (OASDI) to 64 million people, of whom 48 million were retirees and their dependents.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eTraditional income from work represents about 29% of older Americans’ income, whereas it’s roughly 67% of the overall population’s income, so older American rely more on retirement benefits, investment income (16% of older Americans’ income), and government transfers from programs like Social Security \u0026amp; Medicare (37% of older Americans’ income). Income from retirement plans \u0026amp; investments has become harder to predict amid the market volatility that has occurred during the COVID-19 pandemic.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eOlder Americans’ sources of income are very different than those of younger Americans who are still in the workforce, as their wage income is augmented by retirement benefits, investments, Social Security income, \u0026amp; Medicare which helps offset medical costs. This\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/how-will-covid-19-affect-income-older-americans/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUSAFacts chart breaks down the average income of Americans age 65 and older\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e:\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-iframe\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe frameborder=\\\"0\\\" allowfullscreen=\\\"true\\\" id=\\\"null\\\" src=\\\"https://usafacts.org/embed/chart/?adjustment\u0026amp;autosize=true\u0026amp;axisTextColor=%23616161\u0026amp;chartType=3\u0026amp;margins=%5Bobject%20Object%5D\u0026amp;metrics=%5B%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu1320%22%2C%22labelText%22%3A%22Wages%22%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu1321%22%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu1322%22%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu1323%22%2C%22labelText%22%3A%22Investments%22%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu1324%22%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu1325%22%2C%22labelText%22%3A%22Other%20transfers%22%7D%5D\u0026amp;source=SOTU\u0026amp;title=\u0026amp;titleFontSize=0\u0026amp;titleHorizontalAlignment=center\\\" class=\\\"null\\\" style=\\\"null\\\" width=\\\"100%\\\" height=\\\"520\\\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eWage income continues to comprise a significant amount of older Americans’ income, as one-in-five over age 65 are employed or seeking employment so they’re included in the labor force participation rate. This\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/how-will-covid-19-affect-income-older-americans/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUSAFacts chart shows how the labor force participation rate among Americans age 65 or older\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;has changed over time:\u0026nbsp;\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-iframe\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe frameborder=\\\"0\\\" allowfullscreen=\\\"true\\\" id=\\\"null\\\" src=\\\"https://usafacts.org/embed/chart/?adjustment\u0026amp;autosize=true\u0026amp;axisTextColor=%23616161\u0026amp;chartType=0\u0026amp;margins=%5Bobject%20Object%5D\u0026amp;metrics=%5B%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu1327%22%2C%22labelText%22%3A%22Labor%20force%20participation%20%2865%2B%29%22%7D%5D\u0026amp;source=SOTU\u0026amp;title=Income%20of%20the%2065%2B%20Population\u0026amp;titleFontSize=0\u0026amp;titleHorizontalAlignment=center\\\" class=\\\"null\\\" style=\\\"null\\\" width=\\\"100%\\\" height=\\\"520\\\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eMost older Americans work in management (8.2%) or sales \u0026amp; office occupational (7.3%) roles. The industry with the highest concentration of older Americans in the workforce is agriculture (17.3%), while repair \u0026amp; maintenance work, labor unions, and arts, entertainment, \u0026amp; recreation are also popular industries.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eDuring the economic lockdowns imposed by states \u0026amp; localities to slow the spread of the coronavirus pandemic, the\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/april-2020-unemployment-rate-covid-19-states/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eunemployment rate of age 65+ Americans jumped\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;from 3.7% in March to 15.6% in April compared to a jump from 4.4% to 14.7% for the entire population over age 16.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eBecause of the size of the baby boomer generation and the upward trend in the labor force participation by Americans age 65 and up, their share as a proportion of the overall workforce has increased as this USAFacts shows:\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-iframe\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe frameborder=\\\"0\\\" allowfullscreen=\\\"true\\\" id=\\\"null\\\" src=\\\"https://usafacts.org/embed/chart/?adjustment\u0026amp;autosize=true\u0026amp;axisTextColor=%23616161\u0026amp;chartType=0\u0026amp;margins=%5Bobject%20Object%5D\u0026amp;metrics=%5B%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu1326%22%2C%22labelText%22%3A%2265%2B%20as%20proportion%20of%20workforce%22%7D%5D\u0026amp;source=SOTU\u0026amp;startYear=1949\u0026amp;title=\u0026amp;titleFontSize=0\u0026amp;titleHorizontalAlignment=center\\\" class=\\\"null\\\" style=\\\"null\\\" width=\\\"100%\\\" height=\\\"520\\\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eLabor Dept. data indicates that 137 million Americans participated in pension plans in 2017, three-fourths of whom participated in defined contribution plans like 401(k)s which workers contribute a set amount of money into \u0026amp; receive an amount based on its performance; while one-fourths of whom participated in defined benefit plans which provided workers a promised, specific amount of money monthly. This\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/how-will-covid-19-affect-income-older-americans/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUSAFacts chart shows the divergence of the defined contribution \u0026amp; defined benefit retirement plans\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e:\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-iframe\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe frameborder=\\\"0\\\" allowfullscreen=\\\"true\\\" id=\\\"null\\\" src=\\\"https://usafacts.org/embed/chart/?adjustment\u0026amp;autosize=true\u0026amp;axisTextColor=%23616161\u0026amp;chartType=0\u0026amp;margins=%5Bobject%20Object%5D\u0026amp;metrics=%5B%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu1328%22%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu1329%22%7D%5D\u0026amp;source=SOTU\u0026amp;startYear=1949\u0026amp;title=\u0026amp;titleFontSize=0\u0026amp;titleHorizontalAlignment=center\\\" class=\\\"null\\\" style=\\\"null\\\" width=\\\"100%\\\" height=\\\"520\\\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003ePart of the reason for the decline in defined benefit pension plans have declined is that some pension plans have become insolvent because they failed to achieve the necessary returns to fulfill the promised benefits. The volatility of the COVID-19 pandemic has only worsened the outlook for some of those defined benefit pension plans.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e— Eric Revell\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(Photo Credit: iStock.com /\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.istockphoto.com/photo/senior-woman-at-home-gm1145457577-308322037\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eEva-Katalin\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\",\"user_id\":824038,\"cta_prompt\":\"\",\"cta_type\":\"share\",\"cta_text\":\"\",\"cta_url\":\"\",\"image_urls\":{\"large\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/e8209f/iStock-1145457577.jpg\",\"medium\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/e8209f/iStock-1145457577.jpg\",\"small\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/e8209f/iStock-1145457577.jpg\",\"thumb\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/e8209f/iStock-1145457577.jpg\",\"xsmall\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/e8209f/iStock-1145457577.jpg\"},\"profile_id\":1527,\"action_count\":6,\"html_content\":\"\u003cp class='article-byline'\u003eby \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.causes.com/cause/public-health-resource-center\\\"\u003eCovid-19 Health Resource Center\u003c/a\u003e | 8.5.20\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis content leverages data from USAFacts, a non-profit that visualizes governmental data. You can learn more on its \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003ewebsite\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e, \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eFacebook\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e, and \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eTwitter\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003chr\u003e\u003ch3\u003eWhat’s the story?\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eThe income sources relied upon by older Americans, particularly those who are considering or are already in retirement, are different than their younger counterparts. As a result, the older Americans may feel the economic impact of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic differently.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eHow many older Americans are there \u0026amp; where does their income come from?\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eAccording to data from the Census Bureau, as of 2018 there were 72.7 million Americans over the age of 60 and representing 22% of the U.S. population. For the last decade, 10,000 Americans have turned 65 which is a common retirement age.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eIn 2019, the Social Security Administration (SSA) gave Old-Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance (OASDI) to 64 million people, of whom 48 million were retirees and their dependents.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eTraditional income from work represents about 29% of older Americans’ income, whereas it’s roughly 67% of the overall population’s income, so older American rely more on retirement benefits, investment income (16% of older Americans’ income), and government transfers from programs like Social Security \u0026amp; Medicare (37% of older Americans’ income). Income from retirement plans \u0026amp; investments has become harder to predict amid the market volatility that has occurred during the COVID-19 pandemic.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eOlder Americans’ sources of income are very different than those of younger Americans who are still in the workforce, as their wage income is augmented by retirement benefits, investments, Social Security income, \u0026amp; Medicare which helps offset medical costs. This \u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/how-will-covid-19-affect-income-older-americans/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUSAFacts chart breaks down the average income of Americans age 65 and older\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e:\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-iframe\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe frameborder=\\\"0\\\" allowfullscreen=\\\"true\\\" id=\\\"null\\\" src=\\\"https://usafacts.org/embed/chart/?adjustment\u0026amp;autosize=true\u0026amp;axisTextColor=%23616161\u0026amp;chartType=3\u0026amp;margins=%5Bobject%20Object%5D\u0026amp;metrics=%5B%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu1320%22%2C%22labelText%22%3A%22Wages%22%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu1321%22%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu1322%22%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu1323%22%2C%22labelText%22%3A%22Investments%22%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu1324%22%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu1325%22%2C%22labelText%22%3A%22Other%20transfers%22%7D%5D\u0026amp;source=SOTU\u0026amp;title=\u0026amp;titleFontSize=0\u0026amp;titleHorizontalAlignment=center\\\" class=\\\"null\\\" style=\\\"\\\" width=\\\"100%\\\" height=\\\"520\\\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eWage income continues to comprise a significant amount of older Americans’ income, as one-in-five over age 65 are employed or seeking employment so they’re included in the labor force participation rate. This \u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/how-will-covid-19-affect-income-older-americans/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUSAFacts chart shows how the labor force participation rate among Americans age 65 or older\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e has changed over time: \u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-iframe\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe frameborder=\\\"0\\\" allowfullscreen=\\\"true\\\" id=\\\"null\\\" src=\\\"https://usafacts.org/embed/chart/?adjustment\u0026amp;autosize=true\u0026amp;axisTextColor=%23616161\u0026amp;chartType=0\u0026amp;margins=%5Bobject%20Object%5D\u0026amp;metrics=%5B%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu1327%22%2C%22labelText%22%3A%22Labor%20force%20participation%20%2865%2B%29%22%7D%5D\u0026amp;source=SOTU\u0026amp;title=Income%20of%20the%2065%2B%20Population\u0026amp;titleFontSize=0\u0026amp;titleHorizontalAlignment=center\\\" class=\\\"null\\\" style=\\\"\\\" width=\\\"100%\\\" height=\\\"520\\\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eMost older Americans work in management (8.2%) or sales \u0026amp; office occupational (7.3%) roles. The industry with the highest concentration of older Americans in the workforce is agriculture (17.3%), while repair \u0026amp; maintenance work, labor unions, and arts, entertainment, \u0026amp; recreation are also popular industries.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eDuring the economic lockdowns imposed by states \u0026amp; localities to slow the spread of the coronavirus pandemic, the \u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/april-2020-unemployment-rate-covid-19-states/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eunemployment rate of age 65+ Americans jumped\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e from 3.7% in March to 15.6% in April compared to a jump from 4.4% to 14.7% for the entire population over age 16.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eBecause of the size of the baby boomer generation and the upward trend in the labor force participation by Americans age 65 and up, their share as a proportion of the overall workforce has increased as this USAFacts shows:\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-iframe\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe frameborder=\\\"0\\\" allowfullscreen=\\\"true\\\" id=\\\"null\\\" src=\\\"https://usafacts.org/embed/chart/?adjustment\u0026amp;autosize=true\u0026amp;axisTextColor=%23616161\u0026amp;chartType=0\u0026amp;margins=%5Bobject%20Object%5D\u0026amp;metrics=%5B%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu1326%22%2C%22labelText%22%3A%2265%2B%20as%20proportion%20of%20workforce%22%7D%5D\u0026amp;source=SOTU\u0026amp;startYear=1949\u0026amp;title=\u0026amp;titleFontSize=0\u0026amp;titleHorizontalAlignment=center\\\" class=\\\"null\\\" style=\\\"\\\" width=\\\"100%\\\" height=\\\"520\\\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eLabor Dept. data indicates that 137 million Americans participated in pension plans in 2017, three-fourths of whom participated in defined contribution plans like 401(k)s which workers contribute a set amount of money into \u0026amp; receive an amount based on its performance; while one-fourths of whom participated in defined benefit plans which provided workers a promised, specific amount of money monthly. This \u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/how-will-covid-19-affect-income-older-americans/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUSAFacts chart shows the divergence of the defined contribution \u0026amp; defined benefit retirement plans\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e:\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-iframe\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe frameborder=\\\"0\\\" allowfullscreen=\\\"true\\\" id=\\\"null\\\" src=\\\"https://usafacts.org/embed/chart/?adjustment\u0026amp;autosize=true\u0026amp;axisTextColor=%23616161\u0026amp;chartType=0\u0026amp;margins=%5Bobject%20Object%5D\u0026amp;metrics=%5B%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu1328%22%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu1329%22%7D%5D\u0026amp;source=SOTU\u0026amp;startYear=1949\u0026amp;title=\u0026amp;titleFontSize=0\u0026amp;titleHorizontalAlignment=center\\\" class=\\\"null\\\" style=\\\"\\\" width=\\\"100%\\\" height=\\\"520\\\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003ePart of the reason for the decline in defined benefit pension plans have declined is that some pension plans have become insolvent because they failed to achieve the necessary returns to fulfill the promised benefits. The volatility of the COVID-19 pandemic has only worsened the outlook for some of those defined benefit pension plans.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e— Eric Revell\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(Photo Credit: iStock.com / \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.istockphoto.com/photo/senior-woman-at-home-gm1145457577-308322037\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eEva-Katalin\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\",\"comment_count\":2,\"issue_slugs\":[\"health\",\"aging\",\"government\",\"medicare-medicaid\"],\"created_at\":\"2020-07-21T16:16:09.120Z\",\"status\":\"published\",\"snippet\":\"This content leverages data from USAFacts, a non-profit that visualizes governmental data. You can learn more on\",\"html_byline\":\"\u003cp class='article-byline'\u003eby \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.causes.com/cause/public-health-resource-center\\\"\u003eCovid-19 Health Resource Center\u003c/a\u003e | 8.5.20\u003c/p\u003e\",\"share_count\":4,\"reaction_config_id\":null,\"is_countable_article\":false,\"published_at\":\"2020-08-05T16:16:09.854Z\",\"allow_advocacy\":false,\"signed\":false,\"signatures_count\":null,\"signatures_goal\":100,\"signable_progress\":0,\"video_url\":null,\"video_dimensions\":null,\"video_aspect_ratio\":null,\"formatted_publish_date\":\"8.5.20\",\"issue_ids\":[\"government\",\"health\",\"aging\",\"medicare-medicaid\"]},{\"title\":\"COVID-19 is Claiming the Lives of Blacks \u0026 Hispanics at Higher Rates Than Asians \u0026 Whites\",\"id\":45492,\"slug\":\"45492-covid-19-claiming-lives-blacks-hispanics-higher-rates-asians-whites\",\"links\":{\"self\":\"https://www.causes.com/articles/45492-covid-19-claiming-lives-blacks-hispanics-higher-rates-asians-whites\",\"article_comments\":\"/api/articles/45492-covid-19-claiming-lives-blacks-hispanics-higher-rates-asians-whites/comments\",\"signatures\":\"/api/v3/articles/45492/signatures?include=user\"},\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis content leverages data from USAFacts, a non-profit that visualizes governmental data. You can learn more on its\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003ewebsite\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e,\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eFacebook\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e, and\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eTwitter\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003chr\u003e\u003ch3\u003eWhat’s the story?\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eBlack and Hispanic Americans are dying from coronavirus (COVID-19) at higher rates than their white peers,\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/covid-deaths-race-state-age-black-hispanic-white/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eaccording to Centers for Disease Control Prevention (CDC) data compiled by USAFacts\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eAfter adjusting for population, the COVID-19 death rates for Black and Hispanic Americans are higher than those of White \u0026amp; Asian Americans in every age group.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eIn all age groups, Black people are experiencing the highest death rates, while death rates among Asians generally fall between those of White \u0026amp; Hispanic populations as this\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/covid-deaths-race-state-age-black-hispanic-white/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUSAFacts chart\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;shows:\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-iframe\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe frameborder=\\\"0\\\" allowfullscreen=\\\"true\\\" id=\\\"null\\\" src=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/covid-deaths-race-state-age-black-hispanic-white/embed/1/?\\\" class=\\\"null\\\" style=\\\"null\\\" width=\\\"100%\\\" height=\\\"520\\\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eThe gap between Black \u0026amp; Hispanic Americans and their White counterparts is at its largest in younger age groups. This\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/covid-deaths-race-state-age-black-hispanic-white/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUSAFacts chart\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;breaks down the disparity by age group, which shows that, for example, in the 35-44 age group Black people are over 8 times more likely to die than Whites, while Hispanics are over 7 times more likely to die than Whites:\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-iframe\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe frameborder=\\\"0\\\" allowfullscreen=\\\"true\\\" id=\\\"null\\\" src=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/covid-deaths-race-state-age-black-hispanic-white/embed/3/?\\\" class=\\\"null\\\" style=\\\"null\\\" width=\\\"100%\\\" height=\\\"520\\\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eThe disparities in COVID-19 death rates vary not only among racial groups, but between states. For example, the COVID-19 death rate for Blacks over the age of 65 in Wisconsin was 9.9 times higher than Whites as this\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/covid-deaths-race-state-age-black-hispanic-white/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUSAFacts chart\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;shows:\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-iframe\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe frameborder=\\\"0\\\" allowfullscreen=\\\"true\\\" id=\\\"null\\\" src=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/covid-deaths-race-state-age-black-hispanic-white/embed/7/?\\\" class=\\\"null\\\" style=\\\"null\\\" width=\\\"100%\\\" height=\\\"520\\\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eUSAFacts notes:\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cblockquote\u003e“As this data shows, tracking the experience of COVID-19 by race and age is critical to understanding which populations are being disproportionately impacted by the pandemic. It is essential that the CDC continues to update this data. It is also critical for more state and local public health agencies to disaggregate their COVID-19 data by race for a fuller account of differences by state. With this data, public health officials can target policies to best address the disparities in death rates experienced by racial groups shown in the CDC data.”\u003c/blockquote\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e— Eric Revell\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(Photo Credit: iStock.com /\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.istockphoto.com/photo/pathogenic-viruses-causing-infection-in-host-organism-viral-disease-outbreak-3d-gm1208691882-349467594\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eJONGHO SHIN\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\",\"user_id\":824038,\"cta_prompt\":\"\",\"cta_type\":\"share\",\"cta_text\":\"\",\"cta_url\":\"\",\"image_urls\":{\"large\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/d1e387/iStock-1208691882.jpg\",\"medium\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/d1e387/iStock-1208691882.jpg\",\"small\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/d1e387/iStock-1208691882.jpg\",\"thumb\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/d1e387/iStock-1208691882.jpg\",\"xsmall\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/d1e387/iStock-1208691882.jpg\"},\"profile_id\":1527,\"action_count\":12,\"html_content\":\"\u003cp class='article-byline'\u003eby \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.causes.com/cause/public-health-resource-center\\\"\u003eCovid-19 Health Resource Center\u003c/a\u003e | 8.4.20\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis content leverages data from USAFacts, a non-profit that visualizes governmental data. You can learn more on its \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003ewebsite\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e, \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eFacebook\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e, and \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eTwitter\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003chr\u003e\u003ch3\u003eWhat’s the story?\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eBlack and Hispanic Americans are dying from coronavirus (COVID-19) at higher rates than their white peers, \u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/covid-deaths-race-state-age-black-hispanic-white/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eaccording to Centers for Disease Control Prevention (CDC) data compiled by USAFacts\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eAfter adjusting for population, the COVID-19 death rates for Black and Hispanic Americans are higher than those of White \u0026amp; Asian Americans in every age group.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eIn all age groups, Black people are experiencing the highest death rates, while death rates among Asians generally fall between those of White \u0026amp; Hispanic populations as this \u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/covid-deaths-race-state-age-black-hispanic-white/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUSAFacts chart\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e shows:\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-iframe\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe frameborder=\\\"0\\\" allowfullscreen=\\\"true\\\" id=\\\"null\\\" src=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/covid-deaths-race-state-age-black-hispanic-white/embed/1/?\\\" class=\\\"null\\\" style=\\\"\\\" width=\\\"100%\\\" height=\\\"520\\\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eThe gap between Black \u0026amp; Hispanic Americans and their White counterparts is at its largest in younger age groups. This \u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/covid-deaths-race-state-age-black-hispanic-white/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUSAFacts chart\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e breaks down the disparity by age group, which shows that, for example, in the 35-44 age group Black people are over 8 times more likely to die than Whites, while Hispanics are over 7 times more likely to die than Whites:\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-iframe\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe frameborder=\\\"0\\\" allowfullscreen=\\\"true\\\" id=\\\"null\\\" src=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/covid-deaths-race-state-age-black-hispanic-white/embed/3/?\\\" class=\\\"null\\\" style=\\\"\\\" width=\\\"100%\\\" height=\\\"520\\\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eThe disparities in COVID-19 death rates vary not only among racial groups, but between states. For example, the COVID-19 death rate for Blacks over the age of 65 in Wisconsin was 9.9 times higher than Whites as this \u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/covid-deaths-race-state-age-black-hispanic-white/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUSAFacts chart\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e shows:\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-iframe\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe frameborder=\\\"0\\\" allowfullscreen=\\\"true\\\" id=\\\"null\\\" src=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/covid-deaths-race-state-age-black-hispanic-white/embed/7/?\\\" class=\\\"null\\\" style=\\\"\\\" width=\\\"100%\\\" height=\\\"520\\\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eUSAFacts notes:\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cblockquote\u003e“As this data shows, tracking the experience of COVID-19 by race and age is critical to understanding which populations are being disproportionately impacted by the pandemic. It is essential that the CDC continues to update this data. It is also critical for more state and local public health agencies to disaggregate their COVID-19 data by race for a fuller account of differences by state. With this data, public health officials can target policies to best address the disparities in death rates experienced by racial groups shown in the CDC data.”\u003c/blockquote\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e— Eric Revell\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(Photo Credit: iStock.com / \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.istockphoto.com/photo/pathogenic-viruses-causing-infection-in-host-organism-viral-disease-outbreak-3d-gm1208691882-349467594\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eJONGHO SHIN\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\",\"comment_count\":6,\"issue_slugs\":[\"health\",\"equality-diversity-and-inclusion\",\"civil-rights\",\"government\"],\"created_at\":\"2020-07-21T16:14:51.908Z\",\"status\":\"published\",\"snippet\":\"This content leverages data from USAFacts, a non-profit that visualizes governmental data. You can learn more on\",\"html_byline\":\"\u003cp class='article-byline'\u003eby \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.causes.com/cause/public-health-resource-center\\\"\u003eCovid-19 Health Resource Center\u003c/a\u003e | 8.4.20\u003c/p\u003e\",\"share_count\":6,\"reaction_config_id\":null,\"is_countable_article\":false,\"published_at\":\"2020-08-04T16:14:52.631Z\",\"allow_advocacy\":false,\"signed\":false,\"signatures_count\":null,\"signatures_goal\":100,\"signable_progress\":0,\"video_url\":null,\"video_dimensions\":null,\"video_aspect_ratio\":null,\"formatted_publish_date\":\"8.4.20\",\"issue_ids\":[\"civil-rights\",\"government\",\"equality-diversity-and-inclusion\",\"health\"]},{\"title\":\"Gilead Announces $3,120 Price Tag for Its COVID-19 Treatment Remdesivir\",\"id\":45491,\"slug\":\"45491-gilead-announces-3-120-price-tag-covid-19-treatment-remdesivir\",\"links\":{\"self\":\"https://www.causes.com/articles/45491-gilead-announces-3-120-price-tag-covid-19-treatment-remdesivir\",\"article_comments\":\"/api/articles/45491-gilead-announces-3-120-price-tag-covid-19-treatment-remdesivir/comments\",\"signatures\":\"/api/v3/articles/45491/signatures?include=user\"},\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003eGilead Sciences has announced pricing for remdesivir, the first medicine shown to have an impact on COVID-19. The four-digit price tag for a five-day course has raised some eyebrows.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch2\u003eWhat's the cost?\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003ePricing for five-day remdesivir courses will be tiered as follows:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eGovernments in the developed world - including the U.S. Indian Health Services (IHS) and Dept. of Veterans Affairs (VA) - will be charged $2,340.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eU.S. insurers, Medicare, and Medicaid will pay $3,120 or 33% more than governments.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eCountries in the developing world will receive remdesivir at greatly reduced prices through generic manufacturers to which Gilead has licensed production.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch2\u003eIs the price appropriate?\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ch3\u003eIndependent price analysis\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eAccording to independent analyses by the\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://icer-review.org/announcements/updated_icer-covid_models_june_24/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eInstitute for Clinical and Economic Review (ICER)\u003c/a\u003e, a nonprofit that sets benchmarks for which it believes are fair drug prices for the U.S., remdesivir could be cost-effective at up to $5,080 per treatment course.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eICER also acknowledges that recent studies showing that dexamethasone, a cheap and ubiquitous steroid, could save lives among ventilated COVID-19 patients could push the fair price for remdesivir down to as low as $2,520. That would mean governments would be getting a good deal, but private insurers, Medicare, and Medicaid would be overpaying.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eICER notes that if remdesivir doesn't actually work to save patients' lives, it might be worth as little as $310.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003ePeter Bach, director of the Center for Health Policy and Outcomes at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, says the current data about remdesivir may not support its price.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eRecouping costs\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eAccording to ICER, Gilead may need to charge anywhere from $10 to $1,600 per patient to recoup the cost of producing remdesivir.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eGilead's perspective\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn an interview with STAT, Gilead CEO Daniel O'Day — who wrote an\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://stories.gilead.com/articles/an-open-letter-from-daniel-oday-june-29\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eopen letter\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;explaining the remdesivir pricing decision —argued that the proposed pricing for remdesivir is below market value:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cblockquote\u003e\\\"We spent a lot of time and considerable care and discussion about how to approach the pricing of this medicine. At this price it’s significantly below the value it brings to patients and to society. There is no doubt of that in my mind.\\\"\u003c/blockquote\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn fact, O'Day believes that remdesivir's actual value is much higher than any of the proposed prices. He argues that by merely reducing the time that patients spend in the hospital, remdesivir would save $12,000 per patient.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eCriticism by Congress and watchdogs\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eSome politicians have criticized Gilead's pricing.\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/06/29/gilead-sciences-remdesivir-cost-coronavirus/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eRep. Lloyd Doggett\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;(D-TX) says the price is \\\"outrageous\\\" for \\\"a very modest drug, which taxpayer funding saved from a scrapheap of failures\\\" (the pivotal trial for remdesivir was\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.statnews.com/2020/06/29/gilead-announces-remdesivir-price-covid-19/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003etaxpayer-funded\u003c/a\u003e).\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/06/29/gilead-sciences-remdesivir-cost-coronavirus/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003ePeter Maybarduk\u003c/a\u003e, access to medicines director at Public Citizen, argues that remdesivir should be in the public domain given Gilead's reliance on public funding to develop it:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cblockquote\u003e\\\"In a grotesque display of hubris and disregard for the public, Gilead has priced at several thousand dollars a drug that should be in the public domain. Gilead did not make remdesivir alone. Public funding was indispensable at each stage, and government scientists led the early drug discovery team. Allowing Gilead to set the terms during a pandemic represents a colossal failure of leadership by the Trump administration.”\u003c/blockquote\u003e\u003cp\u003ePublic Citizen contends that remdesivir should cost\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://fortune.com/2020/06/29/gilead-remdesivir-coronavirus-treatment-drug-price-cost/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e$1 a day\u003c/a\u003e, based on calculations that it could be manufactured at scale by generic drugmakers for this price.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch2\u003eShould the cost of remdesivir be capped?\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eAs Vox writer Dylan Scott observes, the United States' lack of government negotiating on drug costs leads to\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2020/6/29/21307528/voxcare-remdesivir-price-coronavirus\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eelevated drug costs\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in the country. This includes the cost for remdesivir.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eHowever, given the expected massive need for remdesivir, it's worth asking: should the federal government step in to cap the price the Gilead can charge for this drug?\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e—Lorelei Yang\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(Image Credit: iStockphoto.com /\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://delivery.gettyimages.com/downloads/1223960456.jpg?k=6\u0026amp;e=5OFBIyExPXBWPfVlXaO_50VLm2L-D8XO--aFosGJ6KVdyZqJizsEbQCyrQErf29NXXbkdHzy5wUxNcARoYZ8jwDf83Dr-2yBAoSrSu1gvD4=\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003edigicomphoto\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\",\"user_id\":824038,\"cta_prompt\":\"\",\"cta_type\":\"share\",\"cta_text\":\"\",\"cta_url\":\"\",\"image_urls\":{\"large\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/a25390/iStock-1223960456.jpg\",\"medium\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/a25390/iStock-1223960456.jpg\",\"small\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/a25390/iStock-1223960456.jpg\",\"thumb\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/a25390/iStock-1223960456.jpg\",\"xsmall\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/a25390/iStock-1223960456.jpg\"},\"profile_id\":1527,\"action_count\":9,\"html_content\":\"\u003cp class='article-byline'\u003eby \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.causes.com/cause/public-health-resource-center\\\"\u003eCovid-19 Health Resource Center\u003c/a\u003e | 7.21.20\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eGilead Sciences has announced pricing for remdesivir, the first medicine shown to have an impact on COVID-19. The four-digit price tag for a five-day course has raised some eyebrows.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch2\u003eWhat's the cost?\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003ePricing for five-day remdesivir courses will be tiered as follows:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eGovernments in the developed world - including the U.S. Indian Health Services (IHS) and Dept. of Veterans Affairs (VA) - will be charged $2,340.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eU.S. insurers, Medicare, and Medicaid will pay $3,120 or 33% more than governments.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eCountries in the developing world will receive remdesivir at greatly reduced prices through generic manufacturers to which Gilead has licensed production.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch2\u003eIs the price appropriate?\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ch3\u003eIndependent price analysis\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eAccording to independent analyses by the \u003ca href=\\\"https://icer-review.org/announcements/updated_icer-covid_models_june_24/\\\"\u003eInstitute for Clinical and Economic Review (ICER)\u003c/a\u003e, a nonprofit that sets benchmarks for which it believes are fair drug prices for the U.S., remdesivir could be cost-effective at up to $5,080 per treatment course.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eICER also acknowledges that recent studies showing that dexamethasone, a cheap and ubiquitous steroid, could save lives among ventilated COVID-19 patients could push the fair price for remdesivir down to as low as $2,520. That would mean governments would be getting a good deal, but private insurers, Medicare, and Medicaid would be overpaying.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eICER notes that if remdesivir doesn't actually work to save patients' lives, it might be worth as little as $310.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003ePeter Bach, director of the Center for Health Policy and Outcomes at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, says the current data about remdesivir may not support its price.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eRecouping costs\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eAccording to ICER, Gilead may need to charge anywhere from $10 to $1,600 per patient to recoup the cost of producing remdesivir.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eGilead's perspective\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn an interview with STAT, Gilead CEO Daniel O'Day — who wrote an \u003ca href=\\\"https://stories.gilead.com/articles/an-open-letter-from-daniel-oday-june-29\\\"\u003eopen letter\u003c/a\u003e explaining the remdesivir pricing decision —argued that the proposed pricing for remdesivir is below market value:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cblockquote\u003e\\\"We spent a lot of time and considerable care and discussion about how to approach the pricing of this medicine. At this price it’s significantly below the value it brings to patients and to society. There is no doubt of that in my mind.\\\"\u003c/blockquote\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn fact, O'Day believes that remdesivir's actual value is much higher than any of the proposed prices. He argues that by merely reducing the time that patients spend in the hospital, remdesivir would save $12,000 per patient.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eCriticism by Congress and watchdogs\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eSome politicians have criticized Gilead's pricing. \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/06/29/gilead-sciences-remdesivir-cost-coronavirus/\\\"\u003eRep. Lloyd Doggett\u003c/a\u003e (D-TX) says the price is \\\"outrageous\\\" for \\\"a very modest drug, which taxpayer funding saved from a scrapheap of failures\\\" (the pivotal trial for remdesivir was \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.statnews.com/2020/06/29/gilead-announces-remdesivir-price-covid-19/\\\"\u003etaxpayer-funded\u003c/a\u003e).\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/06/29/gilead-sciences-remdesivir-cost-coronavirus/\\\"\u003ePeter Maybarduk\u003c/a\u003e, access to medicines director at Public Citizen, argues that remdesivir should be in the public domain given Gilead's reliance on public funding to develop it:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cblockquote\u003e\\\"In a grotesque display of hubris and disregard for the public, Gilead has priced at several thousand dollars a drug that should be in the public domain. Gilead did not make remdesivir alone. Public funding was indispensable at each stage, and government scientists led the early drug discovery team. Allowing Gilead to set the terms during a pandemic represents a colossal failure of leadership by the Trump administration.”\u003c/blockquote\u003e\u003cp\u003ePublic Citizen contends that remdesivir should cost \u003ca href=\\\"https://fortune.com/2020/06/29/gilead-remdesivir-coronavirus-treatment-drug-price-cost/\\\"\u003e$1 a day\u003c/a\u003e, based on calculations that it could be manufactured at scale by generic drugmakers for this price.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch2\u003eShould the cost of remdesivir be capped?\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eAs Vox writer Dylan Scott observes, the United States' lack of government negotiating on drug costs leads to \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2020/6/29/21307528/voxcare-remdesivir-price-coronavirus\\\"\u003eelevated drug costs\u003c/a\u003e in the country. This includes the cost for remdesivir.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eHowever, given the expected massive need for remdesivir, it's worth asking: should the federal government step in to cap the price the Gilead can charge for this drug?\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e—Lorelei Yang\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(Image Credit: iStockphoto.com / \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://delivery.gettyimages.com/downloads/1223960456.jpg?k=6\u0026amp;e=5OFBIyExPXBWPfVlXaO_50VLm2L-D8XO--aFosGJ6KVdyZqJizsEbQCyrQErf29NXXbkdHzy5wUxNcARoYZ8jwDf83Dr-2yBAoSrSu1gvD4=\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003edigicomphoto\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\",\"comment_count\":2,\"issue_slugs\":[\"health\",\"research\",\"science-and-technology\",\"government\"],\"created_at\":\"2020-07-21T16:13:46.627Z\",\"status\":\"published\",\"snippet\":\"Gilead Sciences has announced pricing for remdesivir, the first medicine shown to have an impact on COVID-19. The four-digit\",\"html_byline\":\"\u003cp class='article-byline'\u003eby \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.causes.com/cause/public-health-resource-center\\\"\u003eCovid-19 Health Resource Center\u003c/a\u003e | 7.21.20\u003c/p\u003e\",\"share_count\":6,\"reaction_config_id\":null,\"is_countable_article\":false,\"published_at\":\"2020-07-21T16:13:47.293Z\",\"allow_advocacy\":false,\"signed\":false,\"signatures_count\":null,\"signatures_goal\":100,\"signable_progress\":0,\"video_url\":null,\"video_dimensions\":null,\"video_aspect_ratio\":null,\"formatted_publish_date\":\"7.21.20\",\"issue_ids\":[\"science-and-technology\",\"government\",\"health\",\"research\"]},{\"title\":\"Moderna’s COVID-19 Vaccine Enters Phase 3 Trial\",\"id\":45490,\"slug\":\"45490-moderna-s-covid-19-vaccine-enters-phase-3-trial\",\"links\":{\"self\":\"https://www.causes.com/articles/45490-moderna-s-covid-19-vaccine-enters-phase-3-trial\",\"article_comments\":\"/api/articles/45490-moderna-s-covid-19-vaccine-enters-phase-3-trial/comments\",\"signatures\":\"/api/v3/articles/45490/signatures?include=user\"},\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003eModerna's mRNA-1273, an mRNA vaccine candidate, is expected to enter its Phase 3 study this month. This is exciting news—but what does it mean?\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch2\u003eWhat's a phase 3 trial?\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eA phase 3 trial is the final stage of testing required before a drug candidate can be submitted to the FDA for approval. In a phase 3 trial, a company seeks to prove that its product works in, and is safe for, a broad spectrum of potential patients.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eModerna's phase 3 trial design\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn Moderna's case, the company will test one level of its vaccine, at 100 micrograms delivered in two separate shots. This randomized, placebo-controlled\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://investors.modernatx.com/news-releases/news-release-details/moderna-advances-late-stage-development-its-vaccine-mrna-1273\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003etrial\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;will be conducted in collaboration with the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID). The trial is expected to enroll 30,000 participants, mostly from the U.S.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch2\u003eDoes it work?\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eInitial data is promising, but data from the phase 3 trial is needed to be sure Moderna's vaccine works.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eIn the\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://time.com/5852032/moderna-vaccine-phase-3/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003ephase 2 trial\u003c/a\u003e, which is ongoing, 600 healthy people are being followed for post-injection reactions and safety concerns.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003ePhase 3 trial data will be important for\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://time.com/5852032/moderna-vaccine-phase-3/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eevaluating safety and efficacy\u003c/a\u003e, as the trial is bigger (30,000 versus 600 test subjects) and will include more people with a higher risk of exposure to COVID-19, such as health care workers and long-term care facility residents.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eThe\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.fiercebiotech.com/biotech/moderna-finalizes-design-phase-3-covid-19-vaccine-trial-ahead-july-start\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eprimary objective\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of Moderna's phase 3 trial is to show that mRNA-1273 can prevent symptomatic COVID-19 disease — if it achieves this goal, it will be considered effective, and will likely be approved by the FDA.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch2\u003eWho's funding this?\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eAs one of\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://finance.yahoo.com/news/5-promising-covid-19-vaccines-061050035.html\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003efive vaccine developers\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;chosen to be part of the Trump administration's Operation Warp Speed program to accelerate development of a COVID-19 vaccine, Moderna is receiving federal funding for its COVID-19 vaccine work.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eModerna is using federal government funding to develop, test, and scale up manufacturing of its vaccine candidate.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch2\u003eWhen will it be available?\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe short answer: potentially as early as the third quarter of this year, if all goes right. Moderna is ramping up production capacity in anticipation of a successful phase 3 trial.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eOn Thursday, June 25, Moderna announced a\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-moderna-catalent/moderna-eyes-third-quarter-for-first-doses-of-potential-covid-19-vaccine-with-catalent-deal-idUSKBN23W1SI\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003epartnership\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;with Catalent Inc, a contract drugmaker, to prepare an initial dose of 100 million doses of its COVID-19 vaccine.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eAdditionally, Moderna has made\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-moderna-catalent/moderna-eyes-third-quarter-for-first-doses-of-potential-covid-19-vaccine-with-catalent-deal-idUSKBN23W1SI\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003edeals\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;with the U.S. government and signed a 10-year collaboration with Lonza Group AG, a Swiss contract drugmaker, to produce 500 million doses a year, ramping up to one billion doses in 2021.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eModerna's goal, assuming its vaccine is approved, is to inoculate 300 million people by early 2021.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch2\u003eWhat's the catch?\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eWhile it would be fantastic to have a a COVID-19 vaccine as soon as possible, some believe pharmaceutical companies are inadvisably cutting corners in their haste to develop a COVID-19 vaccine. If this is true, there could be significant safety issues that are missed, which could come back to haunt patients down the line.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFor perspective, consider the following: the normal development timeline for a vaccine is about 10 years. Most companies, including Moderna, developing COVID-19 vaccines are looking to cut their development timelines down to only two or three by conducting simultaneous trials, such as Moderna's overlapping phase 2 and phase 3 trials (under normal circumstances, a phase 3 trial only begins after a phase 2 trial's successful conclusion).\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e—Lorelei Yang\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(Image Credit: iStockphoto.com /\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.istockphoto.com/photo/close-up-medical-syringe-with-a-vaccine-gm1027752634-275539127\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eMarianVejcik\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\",\"user_id\":824038,\"cta_prompt\":\"\",\"cta_type\":\"share\",\"cta_text\":\"\",\"cta_url\":\"\",\"image_urls\":{\"large\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/d6f216/iStock-1027752634.jpg\",\"medium\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/d6f216/iStock-1027752634.jpg\",\"small\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/d6f216/iStock-1027752634.jpg\",\"thumb\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/d6f216/iStock-1027752634.jpg\",\"xsmall\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/d6f216/iStock-1027752634.jpg\"},\"profile_id\":1527,\"action_count\":7,\"html_content\":\"\u003cp class='article-byline'\u003eby \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.causes.com/cause/public-health-resource-center\\\"\u003eCovid-19 Health Resource Center\u003c/a\u003e | 7.12.20\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eModerna's mRNA-1273, an mRNA vaccine candidate, is expected to enter its Phase 3 study this month. This is exciting news—but what does it mean?\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch2\u003eWhat's a phase 3 trial?\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eA phase 3 trial is the final stage of testing required before a drug candidate can be submitted to the FDA for approval. In a phase 3 trial, a company seeks to prove that its product works in, and is safe for, a broad spectrum of potential patients.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eModerna's phase 3 trial design\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn Moderna's case, the company will test one level of its vaccine, at 100 micrograms delivered in two separate shots. This randomized, placebo-controlled \u003ca href=\\\"https://investors.modernatx.com/news-releases/news-release-details/moderna-advances-late-stage-development-its-vaccine-mrna-1273\\\"\u003etrial\u003c/a\u003e will be conducted in collaboration with the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID). The trial is expected to enroll 30,000 participants, mostly from the U.S.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch2\u003eDoes it work?\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eInitial data is promising, but data from the phase 3 trial is needed to be sure Moderna's vaccine works.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eIn the \u003ca href=\\\"https://time.com/5852032/moderna-vaccine-phase-3/\\\"\u003ephase 2 trial\u003c/a\u003e, which is ongoing, 600 healthy people are being followed for post-injection reactions and safety concerns.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003ePhase 3 trial data will be important for \u003ca href=\\\"https://time.com/5852032/moderna-vaccine-phase-3/\\\"\u003eevaluating safety and efficacy\u003c/a\u003e, as the trial is bigger (30,000 versus 600 test subjects) and will include more people with a higher risk of exposure to COVID-19, such as health care workers and long-term care facility residents.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eThe \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.fiercebiotech.com/biotech/moderna-finalizes-design-phase-3-covid-19-vaccine-trial-ahead-july-start\\\"\u003eprimary objective\u003c/a\u003e of Moderna's phase 3 trial is to show that mRNA-1273 can prevent symptomatic COVID-19 disease — if it achieves this goal, it will be considered effective, and will likely be approved by the FDA.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch2\u003eWho's funding this?\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eAs one of \u003ca href=\\\"https://finance.yahoo.com/news/5-promising-covid-19-vaccines-061050035.html\\\"\u003efive vaccine developers\u003c/a\u003e chosen to be part of the Trump administration's Operation Warp Speed program to accelerate development of a COVID-19 vaccine, Moderna is receiving federal funding for its COVID-19 vaccine work.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eModerna is using federal government funding to develop, test, and scale up manufacturing of its vaccine candidate.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch2\u003eWhen will it be available?\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe short answer: potentially as early as the third quarter of this year, if all goes right. Moderna is ramping up production capacity in anticipation of a successful phase 3 trial.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eOn Thursday, June 25, Moderna announced a \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-moderna-catalent/moderna-eyes-third-quarter-for-first-doses-of-potential-covid-19-vaccine-with-catalent-deal-idUSKBN23W1SI\\\"\u003epartnership\u003c/a\u003e with Catalent Inc, a contract drugmaker, to prepare an initial dose of 100 million doses of its COVID-19 vaccine.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eAdditionally, Moderna has made \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-moderna-catalent/moderna-eyes-third-quarter-for-first-doses-of-potential-covid-19-vaccine-with-catalent-deal-idUSKBN23W1SI\\\"\u003edeals\u003c/a\u003e with the U.S. government and signed a 10-year collaboration with Lonza Group AG, a Swiss contract drugmaker, to produce 500 million doses a year, ramping up to one billion doses in 2021.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eModerna's goal, assuming its vaccine is approved, is to inoculate 300 million people by early 2021.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch2\u003eWhat's the catch?\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eWhile it would be fantastic to have a a COVID-19 vaccine as soon as possible, some believe pharmaceutical companies are inadvisably cutting corners in their haste to develop a COVID-19 vaccine. If this is true, there could be significant safety issues that are missed, which could come back to haunt patients down the line.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFor perspective, consider the following: the normal development timeline for a vaccine is about 10 years. Most companies, including Moderna, developing COVID-19 vaccines are looking to cut their development timelines down to only two or three by conducting simultaneous trials, such as Moderna's overlapping phase 2 and phase 3 trials (under normal circumstances, a phase 3 trial only begins after a phase 2 trial's successful conclusion).\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e—Lorelei Yang\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(Image Credit: iStockphoto.com / \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.istockphoto.com/photo/close-up-medical-syringe-with-a-vaccine-gm1027752634-275539127\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eMarianVejcik\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\",\"comment_count\":6,\"issue_slugs\":[\"health\",\"government\",\"medicare-medicaid\",\"business\",\"emergency-management\"],\"created_at\":\"2020-07-21T16:12:18.487Z\",\"status\":\"published\",\"snippet\":\"Moderna's mRNA-1273, an mRNA vaccine candidate, is expected to enter its Phase 3 study this month. 8.6.20\u003c/p\u003e\",\"share_count\":36,\"reaction_config_id\":null,\"is_countable_article\":false,\"published_at\":\"2020-08-07T01:30:42.948Z\",\"allow_advocacy\":true,\"signed\":false,\"signatures_count\":null,\"signatures_goal\":100,\"signable_progress\":0,\"video_url\":null,\"video_dimensions\":null,\"video_aspect_ratio\":null,\"formatted_publish_date\":\"8.6.20\",\"issue_ids\":[\"government\",\"federal-agencies\",\"health\",\"arts-culture-religion\",\"emergency-management\"]},{\"title\":\"People of Color More Likely to Contract, Die from COVID-19\",\"id\":44858,\"slug\":\"44858-people-color-likely-contract-die-covid-19\",\"links\":{\"self\":\"https://www.causes.com/articles/44858-people-color-likely-contract-die-covid-19\",\"article_comments\":\"/api/articles/44858-people-color-likely-contract-die-covid-19/comments\",\"signatures\":\"/api/v3/articles/44858/signatures?include=user\"},\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003eAfrican Americans are at much higher risk of contracting COVID-19 than the rest of the U.S. population. Blacks are also much more likely than white people to die from the novel coronavirus. Indigenous people are dying above their percentage of population in at least three states.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eBelow, we break down the COVID-19 demographic data collected by the \u003ca href=\\\"https://covidtracking.com/race\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eCOVID Racial Tracker\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.apmresearchlab.org/covid/deaths-by-race\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eAPM Research Lab \\\"Color of Coronavirus\\\"\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/d6b0ad/AA%20disparity%20%20%281%29.png\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/3bd1a0/Mortality%20Rate.png\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/f8d286/1.png\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/9e2574/2.png\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/a77388/3.png\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.apmresearchlab.org/covid/deaths-by-race\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eThe APM Research Lab\u003c/a\u003e broke down the above numbers by race:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e1 in 1,850 Black Americans has died\u003c/strong\u003e (or 54.6 deaths per 100,000)\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e1 in 4,000 Latino Americans has died \u003c/strong\u003e(or 24.9 deaths per 100,000)\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e1 in 4,200 Asian Americans has died \u003c/strong\u003e(or 24.3 deaths per 100,000)\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e1 in 4,400 White Americans has died\u003c/strong\u003e (or 22.7 deaths per 100,000)\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003eOr, more bluntly:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cblockquote\u003e\\\"If they had died of COVID-19 at the same rate as White Americans, about 13,000 Black Americans, 1,300 Latino Americans and 300 Asian Americans would still be alive.\\\"\u003c/blockquote\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e—Josh Herman\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(Photo Credits: iStock / \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.istockphoto.com/portfolio/grandriver?mediatype=photography\\\" \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.istockphoto.com/portfolio/Nagaiets?mediatype=photography\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eNagaiets\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\",\"user_id\":824038,\"cta_prompt\":\"\",\"cta_type\":\"share\",\"cta_text\":\"\",\"cta_url\":\"\",\"image_urls\":{\"large\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/aae482/AA%20disparity%20%20%281%29.png\",\"medium\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/aae482/AA%20disparity%20%20%281%29.png\",\"small\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/aae482/AA%20disparity%20%20%281%29.png\",\"thumb\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/aae482/AA%20disparity%20%20%281%29.png\",\"xsmall\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/aae482/AA%20disparity%20%20%281%29.png\"},\"profile_id\":1527,\"action_count\":6,\"html_content\":\"\u003cp class='article-byline'\u003eby \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.causes.com/cause/public-health-resource-center\\\"\u003eCovid-19 Health Resource Center\u003c/a\u003e | 8.7.20\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAfrican Americans are at much higher risk of contracting COVID-19 than the rest of the U.S. population. Blacks are also much more likely than white people to die from the novel coronavirus. Indigenous people are dying above their percentage of population in at least three states.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eBelow, we break down the COVID-19 demographic data collected by the \u003ca href=\\\"https://covidtracking.com/race\\\"\u003eCOVID Racial Tracker\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.apmresearchlab.org/covid/deaths-by-race\\\"\u003eAPM Research Lab \\\"Color of Coronavirus\\\"\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/d6b0ad/AA%20disparity%20%20%281%29.png\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/3bd1a0/Mortality%20Rate.png\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/f8d286/1.png\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/9e2574/2.png\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/a77388/3.png\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.apmresearchlab.org/covid/deaths-by-race\\\"\u003eThe APM Research Lab\u003c/a\u003e broke down the above numbers by race:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\\n\u003cstrong\u003e1 in 1,850 Black Americans has died\u003c/strong\u003e (or 54.6 deaths per 100,000)\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\\n\u003cstrong\u003e1 in 4,000 Latino Americans has died \u003c/strong\u003e(or 24.9 deaths per 100,000)\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\\n\u003cstrong\u003e1 in 4,200 Asian Americans has died \u003c/strong\u003e(or 24.3 deaths per 100,000)\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\\n\u003cstrong\u003e1 in 4,400 White Americans has died\u003c/strong\u003e (or 22.7 deaths per 100,000)\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003eOr, more bluntly:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cblockquote\u003e\\\"If they had died of COVID-19 at the same rate as White Americans, about 13,000 Black Americans, 1,300 Latino Americans and 300 Asian Americans would still be alive.\\\"\u003c/blockquote\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e—Josh Herman\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(Photo Credits: iStock / \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.istockphoto.com/portfolio/grandriver?mediatype=photography\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003egrandriver\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e; \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.istockphoto.com/portfolio/Juanmonino?mediatype=photography\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eJuanmonino\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e; \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.istockphoto.com/portfolio/Nagaiets?mediatype=photography\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eNagaiets\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\",\"comment_count\":5,\"issue_slugs\":[\"government\",\"states\",\"equality-diversity-and-inclusion\",\"health\",\"federal-agencies\"],\"created_at\":\"2020-06-08T19:38:55.829Z\",\"status\":\"published\",\"snippet\":\"African Americans are at much higher risk of contracting COVID-19 than the rest of the U.S. population. Blacks are also much\",\"html_byline\":\"\u003cp class='article-byline'\u003eby \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.causes.com/cause/public-health-resource-center\\\"\u003eCovid-19 Health Resource Center\u003c/a\u003e | 8.7.20\u003c/p\u003e\",\"share_count\":1,\"reaction_config_id\":null,\"is_countable_article\":false,\"published_at\":\"2020-08-07T14:13:23.787Z\",\"allow_advocacy\":false,\"signed\":false,\"signatures_count\":null,\"signatures_goal\":100,\"signable_progress\":0,\"video_url\":null,\"video_dimensions\":null,\"video_aspect_ratio\":null,\"formatted_publish_date\":\"8.7.20\",\"issue_ids\":[\"states\",\"government\",\"federal-agencies\",\"equality-diversity-and-inclusion\",\"health\"]},{\"title\":\"45% of Americans Are Feeling Depressed During the COVID-19 Pandemic\",\"id\":44852,\"slug\":\"44852-45-americans-feeling-depressed-covid-19-pandemic\",\"links\":{\"self\":\"https://www.causes.com/articles/44852-45-americans-feeling-depressed-covid-19-pandemic\",\"article_comments\":\"/api/articles/44852-45-americans-feeling-depressed-covid-19-pandemic/comments\",\"signatures\":\"/api/v3/articles/44852/signatures?include=user\"},\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003eIn addition to affecting\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/visualizations/coronavirus-covid-19-spread-map/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003ehealth\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/unemployment-rate-during-covid-19-highest-among-hispanic-and-black-americans/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eemployment\u003c/a\u003e, the COVID-19 pandemic has had an effect on American education, housing payments, and mental health.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eBeginning on April 23, 2020, the US Census Bureau started conducting its “\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.census.gov/data/tables/2020/demo/hhp/hhp4.html\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eHousehold Pulse Survey\u003c/a\u003e” to study “how people’s lives have been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic.”\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe Census Bureau sent questionnaires to an average of 1.3 million households every week in the first four weeks of the survey. About 6.6% of those households responded.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFour questions related to depression and anxiety offer up-to-date information on Americans’ mental health nationwide, in individual states, and amongst various demographic groups. The most recent data released was collected between May 21 and 26, before the death of George Floyd and nationwide protests against police brutality and racism, but still in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe results show high levels of anxiety and depression compared with a similar annual survey conducted by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in 2018. It should be noted that the CDC survey asked a different question than the Census Bureau.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eRegarding anxiety, 55% of American adults experienced “\u003ca href=\\\"https://www2.census.gov/programs-surveys/demo/tables/hhp/2020/wk4/health2a.xlsx\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003efrequency of feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge\u003c/a\u003e” in the last seven days. A quarter of all respondents reported feeling that way more than half of the days in the last week.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eNational responses (May 21-26): In the past 7 days, How many days were you...\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-video embed-responsive embed-responsive-4by3\\\" style=\\\"cursor: text; padding-bottom: 291.722px; color: rgb(57, 57, 57); font-family: \u0026quot;Open Sans\u0026quot;, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 20.3521px; white-space: pre-wrap;\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe class=\\\"embed-responsive-item\\\" src=\\\"https://usafactsstatic.blob.core.windows.net/public/2020/mental-health-topline/index.html?initialWidth=672\u0026amp;childId=graphic2\u0026amp;parentTitle=45%25%20of%20Americans%20are%20feeling%20down%2C%20depressed%2C%20or%20hopeless%20during%20the%20COVID-19%20pandemic%20-%20USAFacts\u0026amp;parentUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fusafacts.org%2Farticles%2F45-americans-are-feeling-down-depressed-or-hopeless-during-covid-19-pandemic%2F\\\" frameborder=\\\"0\\\" allowfullscreen=\\\"true\\\" controls=\\\"true\\\" style=\\\"width: 729.333px; height: 291.722px;\\\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cp\u003eAbout 47% of Americans said they experienced “not being able to stop or control worrying” at least several days during the past week.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eRegarding depression, about 45% of respondents said they felt “down, depressed, or hopeless” for several days in the previous week. About 18% reported these types of feelings the majority of the days in the past week.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAbout 47% responded to “having little interest or pleasure in doing things” during several days in the past week. 20% of all respondents reported feeling that way the majority of the week.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch2\u003eThe Demographics of Anxiety and Depression\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eFeelings of anxiety and depression are strongly correlated with income. Respondents with lower household incomes, or those who lost some sort of income recently, reported higher frequencies of negative feelings. For example, 68% of respondents in households earning less than $25,000 responded feeling down, depressed, or hopeless several days in the previous week. Only 38% of those in households earning more than $150,000 reported the same feelings.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAbout 57% of the people who reported losing employment income said they felt unable to stop or control worrying several days a week compared with 38% of those who didn’t lose their primary source of income.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003ePercentage of respondents responding feeling this way several days in the past week (May 21-May 26)\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-video embed-responsive embed-responsive-4by3\\\" style=\\\"cursor: text; padding-bottom: 291.722px; color: rgb(57, 57, 57); font-family: \u0026quot;Open Sans\u0026quot;, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 20.3521px; white-space: pre-wrap;\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe class=\\\"embed-responsive-item\\\" src=\\\"https://usafactsstatic.blob.core.windows.net/public/2020/mental-health-covid/index.html?initialWidth=672\u0026amp;childId=graphic\u0026amp;parentTitle=45%25%20of%20Americans%20are%20feeling%20down%2C%20depressed%2C%20or%20hopeless%20during%20the%20COVID-19%20pandemic%20-%20USAFacts\u0026amp;parentUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fusafacts.org%2Farticles%2F45-americans-are-feeling-down-depressed-or-hopeless-during-covid-19-pandemic%2F\\\" frameborder=\\\"0\\\" allowfullscreen=\\\"true\\\" controls=\\\"true\\\" style=\\\"width: 729.333px; height: 291.722px;\\\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe data also shows geographic differences. About 49% of adults in California, Nevada, and Louisiana reported feeling down, depressed, or hopeless several days in the past week compared with 37% of adults in six states — Iowa, Maine, Minnesota, Nebraska, Wisconsin, and Wyoming.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eFeeling down, depressed, or hopeless at least several days in the past week\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-iframe\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe frameborder=\\\"0\\\" allowfullscreen=\\\"true\\\" id=\\\"null\\\" src=\\\"https://usafacts.org/embed/chart/?adjustment\u0026amp;axisTextColor=%23616161\u0026amp;chartType=1\u0026amp;fontSize=14\u0026amp;margins=%5Bobject%20Object%5D\u0026amp;metrics=%5B%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu2054%22%2C%22allStates%22%3Atrue%7D%5D\u0026amp;selectableYears=false\u0026amp;selectedYear=2020\u0026amp;sortRows=false\u0026amp;source=SOTU\u0026amp;startYear=2020\u0026amp;title=Feeling%20down%2C%20depressed%2C%20or%20hopeless%20at%20least%20several%20days%20in%20the%20past%20week%20-%20May%2021-26%2C%20\u0026amp;titleFontSize=14\u0026amp;titleHorizontalAlignment=center\u0026amp;titleVerticalPosition=bottom\\\" class=\\\"null\\\" style=\\\"null\\\" width=\\\"750\\\" height=\\\"520\\\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003ch2\u003eHow this data compares to past data\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe above Census data is looking at depression and anxiety during a specific period of American life: a global pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.cdc.gov/brfss/index.html\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eThe Behavioral Risk Factors Surveillance System\u003c/a\u003e, administered by the CDC, asked in 2018: “Has a doctor, nurse, or other health professional ever told you have a depressive disorder?”\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn 2011, the rate of depression for the US adult population was 17.5%. Since then, it’s been on a mostly steady rise, except for a small dip in 2016 to 17.3%. In 2017, the depression rate rose to 20%; in 2018, the last year data is available, the depression rate for the US adult population was 19.6%.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-iframe\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe frameborder=\\\"0\\\" allowfullscreen=\\\"true\\\" id=\\\"null\\\" src=\\\"https://usafacts.org/embed/chart/?adjustment\u0026amp;chartType=0\u0026amp;metrics=%5B%7B%22id%22%3A31733%7D%5D\u0026amp;parentID=31733\u0026amp;source=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.usafacts.org%2Fapi%2Fv4%2FMetrics\u0026amp;title=Depression\\\" class=\\\"null\\\" style=\\\"null\\\" width=\\\"750\\\" height=\\\"520\\\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cp\u003eHow people are feeling at the moment has traditionally not been easy to quantify with government data. The Census’ new experimental survey offers a rather up-to-date way to assess the state of the nation. While the Census Bureau plans to collect the data for only 90 days, how the survey assesses mental health or any of the other issues it includes may serve as a guide for how to understand the nation’s mood in the future.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGET HELP\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIf you feel like you need someone to talk to, call the\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.samhsa.gov/disaster-preparedness\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eDisaster Distress Helpline\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u0026nbsp;at 1-800-985-5990 or text TalkWithUs to 66746. The service provides free, 24/7, 365-day-a-year crisis counseling and support to people experiencing emotional distress related to natural or human-caused disasters. (Including COVID-19.)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIf you’re worried about harming yourself, help is available at the\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://suicidepreventionlifeline.org/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eNational Suicide Prevention Lifeline\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e. Call 1-800-273-TALK (8255) or\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://suicidepreventionlifeline.org/chat/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003echat online here\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e. The service is free and available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. All calls are confidential.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSOURCES \u0026amp; FOOTNOTES\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca
