(CDC)\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e - \u003c/strong\u003eBehavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS)\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e—Josh Herman\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(Photo Credit: \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.istockphoto.com/portfolio/CasarsaGuru?mediatype=photography\\\" class='article-byline'\u003eby \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.causes.com/cause/public-health-resource-center\\\"\u003eCovid-19 Health Resource Center\u003c/a\u003e | 6.8.20\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn addition to affecting \u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/visualizations/coronavirus-covid-19-spread-map/\\\"\u003ehealth\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/unemployment-rate-during-covid-19-highest-among-hispanic-and-black-americans/\\\"\u003eemployment\u003c/a\u003e, the COVID-19 pandemic has had an effect on American education, housing payments, and mental health.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eBeginning on April 23, 2020, the US Census Bureau started conducting its “\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.census.gov/data/tables/2020/demo/hhp/hhp4.html\\\"\u003eHousehold Pulse Survey\u003c/a\u003e” to study “how people’s lives have been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic.”\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe Census Bureau sent questionnaires to an average of 1.3 million households every week in the first four weeks of the survey. About 6.6% of those households responded.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFour questions related to depression and anxiety offer up-to-date information on Americans’ mental health nationwide, in individual states, and amongst various demographic groups. The most recent data released was collected between May 21 and 26, before the death of George Floyd and nationwide protests against police brutality and racism, but still in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe results show high levels of anxiety and depression compared with a similar annual survey conducted by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in 2018. It should be noted that the CDC survey asked a different question than the Census Bureau.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eRegarding anxiety, 55% of American adults experienced “\u003ca href=\\\"https://www2.census.gov/programs-surveys/demo/tables/hhp/2020/wk4/health2a.xlsx\\\"\u003efrequency of feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge\u003c/a\u003e” in the last seven days. A quarter of all respondents reported feeling that way more than half of the days in the last week.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eNational responses (May 21-26): In the past 7 days, How many days were you...\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-video embed-responsive embed-responsive-4by3\\\" style='cursor: text;padding-bottom:291.722px;color: rgb(57, 57, 57);font-family: \\\"Open Sans\\\", Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size: 20.3521px;white-space: pre-wrap;'\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cp\u003eAbout 47% of Americans said they experienced “not being able to stop or control worrying” at least several days during the past week.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eRegarding depression, about 45% of respondents said they felt “down, depressed, or hopeless” for several days in the previous week. About 18% reported these types of feelings the majority of the days in the past week.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAbout 47% responded to “having little interest or pleasure in doing things” during several days in the past week. 20% of all respondents reported feeling that way the majority of the week.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch2\u003eThe Demographics of Anxiety and Depression\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eFeelings of anxiety and depression are strongly correlated with income. Respondents with lower household incomes, or those who lost some sort of income recently, reported higher frequencies of negative feelings. For example, 68% of respondents in households earning less than $25,000 responded feeling down, depressed, or hopeless several days in the previous week. Only 38% of those in households earning more than $150,000 reported the same feelings.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAbout 57% of the people who reported losing employment income said they felt unable to stop or control worrying several days a week compared with 38% of those who didn’t lose their primary source of income.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003ePercentage of respondents responding feeling this way several days in the past week (May 21-May 26)\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-video embed-responsive embed-responsive-4by3\\\" style='cursor: text;padding-bottom:291.722px;color: rgb(57, 57, 57);font-family: \\\"Open Sans\\\", Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size: 20.3521px;white-space: pre-wrap;'\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe data also shows geographic differences. About 49% of adults in California, Nevada, and Louisiana reported feeling down, depressed, or hopeless several days in the past week compared with 37% of adults in six states — Iowa, Maine, Minnesota, Nebraska, Wisconsin, and Wyoming.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eFeeling down, depressed, or hopeless at least several days in the past week\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-iframe\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe frameborder=\\\"0\\\" allowfullscreen=\\\"true\\\" id=\\\"null\\\" src=\\\"https://usafacts.org/embed/chart/?adjustment\u0026amp;axisTextColor=%23616161\u0026amp;chartType=1\u0026amp;fontSize=14\u0026amp;margins=%5Bobject%20Object%5D\u0026amp;metrics=%5B%7B%22id%22%3A%22sotu2054%22%2C%22allStates%22%3Atrue%7D%5D\u0026amp;selectableYears=false\u0026amp;selectedYear=2020\u0026amp;sortRows=false\u0026amp;source=SOTU\u0026amp;startYear=2020\u0026amp;title=Feeling%20down%2C%20depressed%2C%20or%20hopeless%20at%20least%20several%20days%20in%20the%20past%20week%20-%20May%2021-26%2C%20\u0026amp;titleFontSize=14\u0026amp;titleHorizontalAlignment=center\u0026amp;titleVerticalPosition=bottom\\\" class=\\\"null\\\" style=\\\"\\\" width=\\\"750\\\" height=\\\"520\\\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003ch2\u003eHow this data compares to past data\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe above Census data is looking at depression and anxiety during a specific period of American life: a global pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.cdc.gov/brfss/index.html\\\"\u003eThe Behavioral Risk Factors Surveillance System\u003c/a\u003e, administered by the CDC, asked in 2018: “Has a doctor, nurse, or other health professional ever told you have a depressive disorder?”\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn 2011, the rate of depression for the US adult population was 17.5%. Since then, it’s been on a mostly steady rise, except for a small dip in 2016 to 17.3%. In 2017, the depression rate rose to 20%; in 2018, the last year data is available, the depression rate for the US adult population was 19.6%.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"countable-iframe\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe frameborder=\\\"0\\\" allowfullscreen=\\\"true\\\" id=\\\"null\\\" src=\\\"https://usafacts.org/embed/chart/?adjustment\u0026amp;chartType=0\u0026amp;metrics=%5B%7B%22id%22%3A31733%7D%5D\u0026amp;parentID=31733\u0026amp;source=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.usafacts.org%2Fapi%2Fv4%2FMetrics\u0026amp;title=Depression\\\" class=\\\"null\\\" style=\\\"\\\" width=\\\"750\\\" height=\\\"520\\\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cp\u003eHow people are feeling at the moment has traditionally not been easy to quantify with government data. The Census’ new experimental survey offers a rather up-to-date way to assess the state of the nation. While the Census Bureau plans to collect the data for only 90 days, how the survey assesses mental health or any of the other issues it includes may serve as a guide for how to understand the nation’s mood in the future.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGET HELP\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIf you feel like you need someone to talk to, call the\u003c/em\u003e \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.samhsa.gov/disaster-preparedness\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eDisaster Distress Helpline\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e at 1-800-985-5990 or text TalkWithUs to 66746. The service provides free, 24/7, 365-day-a-year crisis counseling and support to people experiencing emotional distress related to natural or human-caused disasters. (Including COVID-19.)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIf you’re worried about harming yourself, help is available at the\u003c/em\u003e \u003ca href=\\\"https://suicidepreventionlifeline.org/\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eNational Suicide Prevention Lifeline\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e. Call 1-800-273-TALK (8255) or\u003c/em\u003e \u003ca href=\\\"https://suicidepreventionlifeline.org/chat/\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003echat online here\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e. The service is free and available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. All calls are confidential.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSOURCES \u0026amp; FOOTNOTES\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\\n\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.census.gov/householdpulsedata\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUS Census Bureau\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e - \u003c/strong\u003eHousehold Pulse Survey\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\\n\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.cdc.gov/brfss/index.html\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCenters for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e - \u003c/strong\u003eBehavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS)\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e—Josh Herman\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(Photo Credit: \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.istockphoto.com/portfolio/CasarsaGuru?mediatype=photography\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eCasarsaGuru\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e / iStock)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\",\"comment_count\":2,\"issue_slugs\":[\"mental-health\",\"health\",\"states\",\"federal-agencies\"],\"created_at\":\"2020-06-08T17:13:20.172Z\",\"status\":\"published\",\"snippet\":\"In addition to affecting health and employment, the COVID-19 pandemic has had an effect on American education, housing payments,\",\"html_byline\":\"\u003cp class='article-byline'\u003eby \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.causes.com/cause/public-health-resource-center\\\"\u003eCovid-19 Health Resource Center\u003c/a\u003e | 6.8.20\u003c/p\u003e\",\"share_count\":2,\"reaction_config_id\":null,\"is_countable_article\":false,\"published_at\":\"2020-06-08T17:13:20.856Z\",\"allow_advocacy\":false,\"signed\":false,\"signatures_count\":null,\"signatures_goal\":100,\"signable_progress\":0,\"video_url\":null,\"video_dimensions\":null,\"video_aspect_ratio\":null,\"formatted_publish_date\":\"6.8.20\",\"issue_ids\":[\"states\",\"federal-agencies\",\"health\",\"mental-health\"]},{\"title\":\"Summer Plans in a Pandemic — What Is and Isn’t Safe?\",\"id\":44815,\"slug\":\"44815-summer-plans-pandemic-isn-t-safe\",\"links\":{\"self\":\"https://www.causes.com/articles/44815-summer-plans-pandemic-isn-t-safe\",\"article_comments\":\"/api/articles/44815-summer-plans-pandemic-isn-t-safe/comments\",\"signatures\":\"/api/v3/articles/44815/signatures?include=user\"},\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003eWith many of us approaching month two (or more) of quarantine, the itch to go outdoors is starting to feel near-overwhelming. But infectious-disease and public-health experts warn that there's currently no such thing as a zero-risk outing. Even seemingly innocuous activities like sharing a vacation home with another family carries some degree of risk.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch2\u003eWhat determines risk?\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eDr. William Miller, an epidemiologist at Ohio State University, says transmission risk is determined by three factors:\u003c/p\u003e\u003col\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTime\u003c/strong\u003e: Risk increases as the amount of time you spend with others goes up\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSpace\u003c/strong\u003e: Risk increases as the space between you and others decreases\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePeople\u003c/strong\u003e: Risk increases as the number of people with whom you interact goes up\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ol\u003e\u003ch2\u003eHow can risk be minimized?\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eDr. Emily Landon, a hospital epidemiologist and infectious diseases specialist at University of Chicago Medicine, advises:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eOutdoor activities are safer than indoor activities\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eMasks should be worn\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eBigger spaces are better\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch2\u003eRisk levels of summer activities\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ch3\u003eLow risk\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eA pool or beach day, assuming maintenance of social distancing\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eSharing a vacation house with another family, as long as both families have been quarantining and limiting exposure to others\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eCamping, as long as fellow campers have been social distancing and following COVID-19 guidelines\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eGolf, tennis, and other non-contact outdoor sports\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eLow to medium risk\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eStaying at a hotel (time in common areas - such as the lobby, gym, restaurant, and elevator - should be limited)\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eA BYOB background gathering with one other household (risk level is dependent on the other household's adherence to social distancing and COVID-19 precautions)\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eMedium to high risk\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eEating indoors at a restaurant\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eAn outdoor celebration of more than 10 guests (risk goes up as the number of guests increases)\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eGetting a haircut\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eHigh risk\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eAttending \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.countable.us/articles/44607-houses-worship-essential-pandemic\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003ereligious services\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eGoing to a nightclub\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch2\u003eShare your summer plans\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eNow that you know the risk levels of various summertime activities, what —\u0026nbsp;if any —\u0026nbsp;activities do you plan to engage in?\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e—Lorelei Yang\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(Image Credit: iStockphoto.com / \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca Has Killed More Than 100,000 Americans - Here's What That Means\",\"id\":44661,\"slug\":\"44661-coronavirus-killed-100-000-americans-s-means\",\"links\":{\"self\":\"https://www.causes.com/articles/44661-coronavirus-killed-100-000-americans-s-means\",\"article_comments\":\"/api/articles/44661-coronavirus-killed-100-000-americans-s-means/comments\",\"signatures\":\"/api/v3/articles/44661/signatures?include=user\"},\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003eToday, the U.S. reached the tragic milestone of 100,000 deaths from COVID-19.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe number of victims is so staggeringly large, it is difficult to comprehend the magnitude of this devastation. To help convey just how many American lives have been lost, we've used some easier-to-imagine visuals:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg 5.27.20\u003c/p\u003e\",\"share_count\":2,\"reaction_config_id\":null,\"is_countable_article\":false,\"published_at\":\"2020-05-28T02:13:08.970Z\",\"allow_advocacy\":true,\"signed\":false,\"signatures_count\":null,\"signatures_goal\":100,\"signable_progress\":0,\"video_url\":null,\"video_dimensions\":null,\"video_aspect_ratio\":null,\"formatted_publish_date\":\"5.27.20\",\"issue_ids\":[\"government\",\"federal-agencies\",\"health\",\"emergency-management\"]},{\"title\":\"Meat Is a $103B-a-Year Industry — How Will COVID-19 Affect These Numbers?\",\"id\":44446,\"slug\":\"44446-meat-103b-year-industry-covid-19-affect-numbers\",\"links\":{\"self\":\"https://www.causes.com/articles/44446-meat-103b-year-industry-covid-19-affect-numbers\",\"article_comments\":\"/api/articles/44446-meat-103b-year-industry-covid-19-affect-numbers/comments\",\"signatures\":\"/api/v3/articles/44446/signatures?include=user\"},\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eAccording to data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS), about 527,000 people were employed by the animal slaughtering and processing industry in May 2019.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe meat processing industry is grappling with its own COVID-19 outbreak.\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/69/wr/mm6918e3.htm?s_cid=mm6918e3_x\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eAccording to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)\u003c/a\u003e, workers in at least 115 meat and poultry processing plants in 19 states were diagnosed with coronavirus. As of May 8, there were 4,913 cases and 20 deaths in these plants, which employ 130,000 people.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe outbreak led to updated federal safety guidelines for plant workers and even\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://crsreports.congress.gov/product/pdf/IN/IN11366\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eplant closures\u003c/a\u003e. Late in April, President Donald Trump ordered meat processing plants to stay open by classifying them as critical infrastructure.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eLast year, the United States produced 105 billion pounds of meat. That's the equivalent of 320 pounds of poultry, pork, and beef for every US resident. Between cattle, pork, and poultry, there was $102 billion worth of American meat sold.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/3733bf/MeatProd.PNG\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eWho works in the meat industry?\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eAccording to\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://data.bls.gov/oes/#/indOcc/Multiple%20occupations%20for%20one%20industry\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003edata from the Bureau of Labor Statistics\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;(BLS), about 527,000 people were employed by the animal slaughtering and processing industry in May 2019.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eOf those, 324,000 were production workers, which includes people directly involved with the processing of the meat.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eMeat producers tend to earn an average hourly wage of $15.20 compared with the $19.51 average across the entire manufacturing sector.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAccording to the BLS data, there were 73,390 slaughterers and meatpackers (those in the industry working directly with the meat) across the country.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFive states—Texas, North Carolina, Georgia, Minnesota, and Iowa—account for 38% of the nation’s slaughterers and meatpackers:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/179498/MeatEm.PNG\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe United States is the largest cattle producer in the world, with $48.2 billion worth produced in 2019. With $31.8 billion in chicken and $3.8 billion in turkey produced in 2019, the US is also the largest poultry producer in the world. It's the third largest pork producer in the world, with $18.8 billion worth in 2019. About 11.7% of the beef (worth $7.7 billion) produced in the US in 2018 was exported.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eMeat processing plants are key components of the overall meat production industry, and the industry plays a major role in the country’s food supply.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e—Josh Herman\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e(Photo Credit: iStock /\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.istockphoto.com/portfolio/JosieN?mediatype=photography\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eJosieN\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSOURCES \u0026amp; FOOTNOTES\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.ers.usda.gov/topics/animal-products/cattle-beef/statistics-information/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUS Department of Agriculture\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u0026nbsp;-\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003eEconomic Research Service\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://usda.library.cornell.edu/concern/publications/m039k491c\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUS Department of Agriculture\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u0026nbsp;-\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003eEconomics, Statistics and Market Information System\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://data.bls.gov/oes/#/indOcc/Multiple%20occupations%20for%20one%20industry\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBureau of Labor Statistics\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u0026nbsp;-\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003eOccupational Employment Statistics (May 2019)\u003c/p\u003e\",\"user_id\":824038,\"cta_prompt\":\"\",\"cta_type\":\"share\",\"cta_text\":\"\",\"cta_url\":\"\",\"image_urls\":{\"large\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/f77dbd/iStock-1214219330.jpg\",\"medium\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/f77dbd/iStock-1214219330.jpg\",\"small\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/f77dbd/iStock-1214219330.jpg\",\"thumb\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/f77dbd/iStock-1214219330.jpg\",\"xsmall\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/f77dbd/iStock-1214219330.jpg\"},\"profile_id\":1527,\"action_count\":0,\"html_content\":\"\u003cp class='article-byline'\u003eby \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.causes.com/cause/public-health-resource-center\\\"\u003eCovid-19 Health Resource Center\u003c/a\u003e | 5.13.20\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eAccording to data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS), about 527,000 people were employed by the animal slaughtering and processing industry in May 2019.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe meat processing industry is grappling with its own COVID-19 outbreak. \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/69/wr/mm6918e3.htm?s_cid=mm6918e3_x\\\"\u003eAccording to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)\u003c/a\u003e, workers in at least 115 meat and poultry processing plants in 19 states were diagnosed with coronavirus. As of May 8, there were 4,913 cases and 20 deaths in these plants, which employ 130,000 people.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe outbreak led to updated federal safety guidelines for plant workers and even \u003ca href=\\\"https://crsreports.congress.gov/product/pdf/IN/IN11366\\\"\u003eplant closures\u003c/a\u003e. Late in April, President Donald Trump ordered meat processing plants to stay open by classifying them as critical infrastructure.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eLast year, the United States produced 105 billion pounds of meat. That's the equivalent of 320 pounds of poultry, pork, and beef for every US resident. Between cattle, pork, and poultry, there was $102 billion worth of American meat sold.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/3733bf/MeatProd.PNG\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eWho works in the meat industry?\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eAccording to \u003ca href=\\\"https://data.bls.gov/oes/#/indOcc/Multiple%20occupations%20for%20one%20industry\\\"\u003edata from the Bureau of Labor Statistics\u003c/a\u003e (BLS), about 527,000 people were employed by the animal slaughtering and processing industry in May 2019.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eOf those, 324,000 were production workers, which includes people directly involved with the processing of the meat.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eMeat producers tend to earn an average hourly wage of $15.20 compared with the $19.51 average across the entire manufacturing sector.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAccording to the BLS data, there were 73,390 slaughterers and meatpackers (those in the industry working directly with the meat) across the country.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFive states—Texas, North Carolina, Georgia, Minnesota, and Iowa—account for 38% of the nation’s slaughterers and meatpackers:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/179498/MeatEm.PNG\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe United States is the largest cattle producer in the world, with $48.2 billion worth produced in 2019. With $31.8 billion in chicken and $3.8 billion in turkey produced in 2019, the US is also the largest poultry producer in the world. It's the third largest pork producer in the world, with $18.8 billion worth in 2019. About 11.7% of the beef (worth $7.7 billion) produced in the US in 2018 was exported.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eMeat processing plants are key components of the overall meat production industry, and the industry plays a major role in the country’s food supply.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e—Josh Herman\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e(Photo Credit: iStock / \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.istockphoto.com/portfolio/JosieN?mediatype=photography\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eJosieN\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSOURCES \u0026amp; FOOTNOTES\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.ers.usda.gov/topics/animal-products/cattle-beef/statistics-information/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUS Department of Agriculture\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e - \u003c/strong\u003eEconomic Research Service\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca Agriculture\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e - \u003c/strong\u003eEconomics, Statistics and Market Information System\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca 2019)\u003c/p\u003e\",\"comment_count\":0,\"issue_slugs\":[\"food-and-agriculture\",\"animals\",\"government\",\"states\",\"federal-agencies\"],\"created_at\":\"2020-05-13T19:54:11.292Z\",\"status\":\"published\",\"snippet\":\"According 5.13.20\u003c/p\u003e\",\"share_count\":0,\"reaction_config_id\":null,\"is_countable_article\":false,\"published_at\":\"2020-05-13T19:54:12.346Z\",\"allow_advocacy\":true,\"signed\":false,\"signatures_count\":null,\"signatures_goal\":100,\"signable_progress\":0,\"video_url\":null,\"video_dimensions\":null,\"video_aspect_ratio\":null,\"formatted_publish_date\":\"5.13.20\",\"issue_ids\":[\"states\",\"government\",\"federal-agencies\",\"food-and-agriculture\",\"animals\"]},{\"title\":\"See How Much ‘Paycheck Protection Program’ Funding Has Gone to Small Businesses in Your State\",\"id\":44420,\"slug\":\"44420-see-paycheck-protection-program-funding-gone-small-businesses-state\",\"links\":{\"self\":\"https://www.causes.com/articles/44420-see-paycheck-protection-program-funding-gone-small-businesses-state\",\"article_comments\":\"/api/articles/44420-see-paycheck-protection-program-funding-gone-small-businesses-state/comments\",\"signatures\":\"/api/v3/articles/44420/signatures?include=user\"},\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis content leverages data from USAFacts, a non-profit that visualizes governmental data. You can learn more on its\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003ewebsite\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e,\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eFacebook\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e, and\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eTwitter\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003chr\u003e\u003cp\u003eOn April 16th, the\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.countable.us/articles/43327-does-cares-act-help-small-business\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePaycheck Protection Program (PPP)\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that provides forgivable loans for small businesses\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.countable.us/articles/43880-paycheck-protection-program-runs-funds-small-businesses-congress-pass-funding\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eexhausted its initial $350 billion in funding\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;it received under the\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.countable.us/bills/hr748-116\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCARES Act\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;after 13 days of operating. While the\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.countable.us/articles/44001-white-house-democrats-reach-funding-deal-small-business-paycheck-protection-program-hospitals-covid-19-testing\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCongress and the Trump administration enacted a second round\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.countable.us/bills/hr266-116\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePPP funding amounting to $321 billion\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that became on Monday, the complete lending data from the first round offers insights into how small businesses and lenders are using the program.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAccording to\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.sba.gov/sites/default/files/2020-04/PPP%20Deck%20copy.pdf\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSmall Business Administration (SBA) data\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, in the initial round of PPP funding 1.661 million small businesses received a total $342.2 billion in funding from 4,975 lenders (the remaining funds were reserved to cover associated loan fees), and no single lender originated more than 5% of the loans by dollar value. PPP loans are capped at a maximum of $10 million to cover two months of payroll, and the\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.sba.gov/sites/default/files/2020-04/PPP%20Deck%20copy.pdf\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eaverage loan size was $206,000\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn the first round of PPP funding, forgivable loans were provided to businesses in every U.S. state and territory. This chart from USAFacts shows the\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/these-are-states-receiving-most-350-billion-small-business-loans/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003enumber of approved PPP loans in each state\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e:\u003cimg src=\\\"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/qcrRvC4bn0nZsHXjfWHSJ8R0J0gDPTB-UEfChymsAc0mUfBFJE7kmZ3uPVsZfgcFba9HBc0xFNj2rc4lKOJ9dEfe0jmyoIuyJZjJLsNPmCBSowSz3BZK7y1PDqJoEBzaHYrSzrcj\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSmall businesses in Texas received 134,737 loans from the initial round of funding, the most of any state.\u0026nbsp;Other states where small businesses received relatively large numbers of loans include California with 113,000 small business loans; Florida with 88,997 small business loans; and New York with 81,075 small business loans.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eWhile the larger, more populous states saw greater numbers of small business loans approved,\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/these-are-states-receiving-most-350-billion-small-business-loans/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003esmaller, less populated states tended to receive more PPP loan dollars per capita\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;as this chart from USAFacts shows:\u003cimg src=\\\"https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/5WkePKJvxTfVXGFHYfRtcivtj1hM4Icif_guxRl7l-SOUTrzGtMy_FguF9R1UIHWfQMU_UJHJUQNi5I_JqTMBT0YDfVTXTadgSXKEF3KFX9FbB7WpFuF1GqBzG1G-0l2JId3hioA\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe state which saw its small businesses receive the most PPP loan dollars per capita was North Dakota with $2,037 in PPP loans per capita; followed by Minnesota with $1,606; Vermont with $1,597; and South Dakota with $1,552.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe PPP is designed to help small businesses with fewer than 500 employees cover up to two months of payroll and related expenses, up to a maximum of $10 million. As a result, loan amounts were fairly evenly distributed between the smaller and larger businesses within that spectrum. This graphic from\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/these-are-states-receiving-most-350-billion-small-business-loans/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUSAFacts breaks down the proportion of PPP loans made in each size range\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, and shows that the largest cohort was the $350,000 to $1 million range:\u003cimg src=\\\"https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/RIh2f3xOTQOMyiJ_Bhg-gxOL4CsreJ_eO2o2OsSNx8ZBUI_ESljCAEAub6Si01epAm4rBQxg2bRhqgxrrr4QvNXGlUf1IPW8_4qKlg6BWmHb1ru-vUfVQVVykZszTD4id6zoOfyv\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic and the stay-at-home orders it prompted have impacted the operations of small businesses across economic sectors. This chart from USAFacts shows the top five industries that received PPP loans:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/Rqb5cLYqcUOrb6TtwtaTmDTaryx_bpd8Qwr5UoQ-hjkstNZwpmSQvpkQo7FYhJPc_L-OnUPrCsml_grGcQfAeXbwDR7102f6tVwJp4o0B7jlVDWuCu1YemRpEQ7Mcqykk04qb54h\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis table compiled by USAFacts shows the total number of\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/these-are-states-receiving-most-350-billion-small-business-loans/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePPP loans for each industry\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, the dollar amount, and its percentage relative to the entire $350 billion first round of PPP loans:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/ndXkdAAZabxldjBPZ0Oqr7eb8Cohv60WYLxnbbKPGXr6RcVcvqk6zwFBwnKNVCQskLGAiHalt8pRSTbQ1KstswAL6R2nY3ujG_clH7qiVJ0WWUdzlHF-4EZMozgyNe1mkSk-QxFM\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg learn more about the Paycheck Protection Program and how small businesses can apply,\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003ca Revell\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\",\"user_id\":824038,\"cta_prompt\":\"\",\"cta_type\":\"share\",\"cta_text\":\"\",\"cta_url\":\"\",\"image_urls\":{\"large\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/27e83b/iStock-1218429145.jpg\",\"medium\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/27e83b/iStock-1218429145.jpg\",\"small\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/27e83b/iStock-1218429145.jpg\",\"thumb\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/27e83b/iStock-1218429145.jpg\",\"xsmall\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/27e83b/iStock-1218429145.jpg\"},\"profile_id\":1527,\"action_count\":11,\"html_content\":\"\u003cp 5.12.20\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis content leverages data from USAFacts, a non-profit that visualizes governmental data. You can learn more on its \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003ewebsite\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e, \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eFacebook\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e, and \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eTwitter\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003chr\u003e\u003cp\u003eOn April 16th, the \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.countable.us/articles/43327-does-cares-act-help-small-business\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePaycheck Protection Program (PPP)\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e that provides forgivable loans for small businesses \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.countable.us/articles/43880-paycheck-protection-program-runs-funds-small-businesses-congress-pass-funding\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eexhausted its initial $350 billion in funding\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e it received under the \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.countable.us/bills/hr748-116\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCARES Act\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e after 13 days of operating. While the \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.countable.us/articles/44001-white-house-democrats-reach-funding-deal-small-business-paycheck-protection-program-hospitals-covid-19-testing\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCongress and the Trump administration enacted a second round\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e of \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.countable.us/bills/hr266-116\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePPP funding amounting to $321 billion\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e that became on Monday, the complete lending data from the first round offers insights into how small businesses and lenders are using the program.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAccording to \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.sba.gov/sites/default/files/2020-04/PPP%20Deck%20copy.pdf\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSmall Business Administration (SBA) data\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, in the initial round of PPP funding 1.661 million small businesses received a total $342.2 billion in funding from 4,975 lenders (the remaining funds were reserved to cover associated loan fees), and no single lender originated more than 5% of the loans by dollar value. PPP loans are capped at a maximum of $10 million to cover two months of payroll, and the \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.sba.gov/sites/default/files/2020-04/PPP%20Deck%20copy.pdf\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eaverage loan size was $206,000\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn the first round of PPP funding, forgivable loans were provided to businesses in every U.S. state and territory. This chart from USAFacts shows the \u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/these-are-states-receiving-most-350-billion-small-business-loans/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003enumber of approved PPP loans in each state\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e:\u003cimg src=\\\"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/qcrRvC4bn0nZsHXjfWHSJ8R0J0gDPTB-UEfChymsAc0mUfBFJE7kmZ3uPVsZfgcFba9HBc0xFNj2rc4lKOJ9dEfe0jmyoIuyJZjJLsNPmCBSowSz3BZK7y1PDqJoEBzaHYrSzrcj\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSmall businesses in Texas received 134,737 loans from the initial round of funding, the most of any state. Other states where small businesses received relatively large numbers of loans include California with 113,000 small business loans; Florida with 88,997 small business loans; and New York with 81,075 small business loans.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eWhile the larger, more populous states saw greater numbers of small business loans approved, \u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/these-are-states-receiving-most-350-billion-small-business-loans/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003esmaller, less populated states tended to receive more PPP loan dollars per capita\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e as this chart from USAFacts shows:\u003cimg src=\\\"https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/5WkePKJvxTfVXGFHYfRtcivtj1hM4Icif_guxRl7l-SOUTrzGtMy_FguF9R1UIHWfQMU_UJHJUQNi5I_JqTMBT0YDfVTXTadgSXKEF3KFX9FbB7WpFuF1GqBzG1G-0l2JId3hioA\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe state which saw its small businesses receive the most PPP loan dollars per capita was North Dakota with $2,037 in PPP loans per capita; followed by Minnesota with $1,606; Vermont with $1,597; and South Dakota with $1,552. \u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe PPP is designed to help small businesses with fewer than 500 employees cover up to two months of payroll and related expenses, up to a maximum of $10 million. As a result, loan amounts were fairly evenly distributed between the smaller and larger businesses within that spectrum. This graphic from \u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/these-are-states-receiving-most-350-billion-small-business-loans/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUSAFacts breaks down the proportion of PPP loans made in each size range\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, and shows that the largest cohort was the $350,000 to $1 million range:\u003cimg src=\\\"https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/RIh2f3xOTQOMyiJ_Bhg-gxOL4CsreJ_eO2o2OsSNx8ZBUI_ESljCAEAub6Si01epAm4rBQxg2bRhqgxrrr4QvNXGlUf1IPW8_4qKlg6BWmHb1ru-vUfVQVVykZszTD4id6zoOfyv\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic and the stay-at-home orders it prompted have impacted the operations of small businesses across economic sectors. This chart from USAFacts shows the top five industries that received PPP loans:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/Rqb5cLYqcUOrb6TtwtaTmDTaryx_bpd8Qwr5UoQ-hjkstNZwpmSQvpkQo7FYhJPc_L-OnUPrCsml_grGcQfAeXbwDR7102f6tVwJp4o0B7jlVDWuCu1YemRpEQ7Mcqykk04qb54h\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis table compiled by USAFacts shows the total number of \u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/articles/these-are-states-receiving-most-350-billion-small-business-loans/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePPP loans for each industry\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, the dollar amount, and its percentage relative to the entire $350 billion first round of PPP loans:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/ndXkdAAZabxldjBPZ0Oqr7eb8Cohv60WYLxnbbKPGXr6RcVcvqk6zwFBwnKNVCQskLGAiHalt8pRSTbQ1KstswAL6R2nY3ujG_clH7qiVJ0WWUdzlHF-4EZMozgyNe1mkSk-QxFM\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/Oa04W6Q8TVjMMq7EPc6EgE2ipvyzvMiQmNLVmrdVwB6mOh7VIUEwrTez02unxTH8v2_MVCS-4t5eAzV5lPgUSSvltha5QcCWtQx2moQe-aKLAnQWCEEFb7CUuepzkFsii1Qr6QNu\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eTo learn more about the Paycheck Protection Program and how small businesses can apply, \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.countable.us/articles/43575-how-to-apply-small-business-paycheck-protection-program-loans\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eclick here\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eTo learn more about the Paycheck Protection Program and how self-employed individuals can apply, \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.countable.us/articles/43768-apply-paycheck-protection-program-loans-re-self-employed-independent-contractor-gig-economy-worker\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eclick You can learn more on\",\"html_byline\":\"\u003cp class='article-byline'\u003eby \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.causes.com/cause/public-health-resource-center\\\"\u003eCovid-19 Health Resource 5.12.20\u003c/p\u003e\",\"share_count\":11,\"reaction_config_id\":null,\"is_countable_article\":false,\"published_at\":\"2020-05-12T17:48:58.257Z\",\"allow_advocacy\":true,\"signed\":false,\"signatures_count\":null,\"signatures_goal\":100,\"signable_progress\":0,\"video_url\":null,\"video_dimensions\":null,\"video_aspect_ratio\":null,\"formatted_publish_date\":\"5.12.20\",\"issue_ids\":[\"states\",\"federal-agencies\",\"health\",\"small-business\",\"jobs\"]},{\"title\":\"What Will Restaurants Look Like Post-Pandemic?\",\"id\":44419,\"slug\":\"44419-restaurants-look-like-post-pandemic\",\"links\":{\"self\":\"https://www.causes.com/articles/44419-restaurants-look-like-post-pandemic\",\"article_comments\":\"/api/articles/44419-restaurants-look-like-post-pandemic/comments\",\"signatures\":\"/api/v3/articles/44419/signatures?include=user\"},\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003eStates across the U.S. have begun allowing non-essential businesses,\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.eater.com/2020/5/7/21249357/reopening-coronavirus-phases-where-are-restaurants-open-covid-19\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eincluding restaurants\u003c/a\u003e, to\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.eater.com/2020/5/7/21249357/reopening-coronavirus-phases-where-are-restaurants-open-covid-19\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003ereopen—with restrictions\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAlaska\u003c/strong\u003e: diners must have reservations in advance of their meals\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLouisiana\u003c/strong\u003e: no dine-in service, outdoor seating spaces opening without waitstaff and while continuing to observe social distancing measures\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNew Hampshire\u003c/strong\u003e: diners must have reservations in advance of their meals\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTexas\u003c/strong\u003e: restaurants can reopen their dining rooms at 25% capacity\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003eAs the above shows, the reopening of restaurants is likely to be slow, painful, and difficult. With this in mind, it's worth asking, \\\"What does the future of restaurants look like after the pandemic?\\\"\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch2\u003eStepped-up hygiene protocols\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eMeasures to ensure the health of diners and employees will be of paramount importance as long as COVID-19 remains a threat. These will likely include:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eMasks for diners and waitstaff\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eAdditional cleaning protocols\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eDisposable menus\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch2\u003eReduced capacity, possibly forever\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eIt's possible that COVID-19 will fundamentally alter the future of the in-restaurant experience. If diners never return to feeling comfortable sitting elbow-to-elbow with each other, there's a real chance spaced-out seating and reduced dining room capacities will become the new normal.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eNaomi Pomeroy - owner of James Beard Award-winning fine-dining restaurant Beast, as well as Expatriate, a small bar across the street from it - expresses this fear in an interview with\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/05/04/restaurants-some-states-fire-up-again-proprietors-wonder-if-rich-dining-landscape-will-ever-be-same/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe Washington Post\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cblockquote\u003e\\\"Beast will never exist again. I had two communal tables where you sit right next to people you don’t know. I have to shut off a concept I spent 12 years building, and I don’t know yet what the next thing is going to be.”\u003c/blockquote\u003e\u003cp\u003eSome possibilities facing restaurants in the future are:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eDining room capacity reductions of 50% or more\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eSignificant reduction of bar seating capacity\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eEarly closing hours (e.g., legally enforced last call at 10 p.m.)\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch2\u003eService changes\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eThere's also a chance that restaurants' business models will have to fundamentally change. In a world where fewer people can - and want - to sit in a dining room, restaurants\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.pennlive.com/coronavirus/2020/05/what-does-the-future-of-restaurants-look-like-as-pa-eases-guidelines.html\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003emay\u003c/a\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003ePivot to take out as their primary business\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eTransition to grab-and-go concepts\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eMove to food trucks instead of brick-and-mortar locations\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eCheck customers' temperatures before allowing them to enter\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eDiscourage guests from congregating in bars or lobbies\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eLimit menu options to boost margins\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eWhat do you think?\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eHow do you think restaurants' businesses will change post-pandemic? Will changes need to put in place before you dine out again? Are you planning on returning to business-as-usual? Take action above, then share your thoughts below.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e—Lorelei Yang\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(Image Credit: iStockphoto.com 5.12.20\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eStates across the U.S. have begun allowing non-essential businesses, \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.eater.com/2020/5/7/21249357/reopening-coronavirus-phases-where-are-restaurants-open-covid-19\\\"\u003eincluding restaurants\u003c/a\u003e, to \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.eater.com/2020/5/7/21249357/reopening-coronavirus-phases-where-are-restaurants-open-covid-19\\\"\u003ereopen—with restrictions\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\\n\u003cstrong\u003eAlaska\u003c/strong\u003e: diners must have reservations in advance of their meals\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\\n\u003cstrong\u003eLouisiana\u003c/strong\u003e: no dine-in service, outdoor seating spaces opening without waitstaff and while continuing to observe social distancing measures\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\\n\u003cstrong\u003eNew Hampshire\u003c/strong\u003e: diners must have reservations in advance of their meals\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\\n\u003cstrong\u003eTexas\u003c/strong\u003e: restaurants can reopen their dining rooms at 25% capacity\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003eAs the above shows, the reopening of restaurants is likely to be slow, painful, and difficult. With this in mind, it's worth asking, \\\"What does the future of restaurants look like after the pandemic?\\\"\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch2\u003eStepped-up hygiene protocols\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eMeasures to ensure the health of diners and employees will be of paramount importance as long as COVID-19 remains a threat. These will likely include:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eMasks for diners and waitstaff\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eAdditional cleaning protocols\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eDisposable menus\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch2\u003eReduced capacity, possibly forever\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eIt's possible that COVID-19 will fundamentally alter the future of the in-restaurant experience. If diners never return to feeling comfortable sitting elbow-to-elbow with each other, there's a real chance spaced-out seating and reduced dining room capacities will become the new normal.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eNaomi Pomeroy - owner of James Beard Award-winning fine-dining restaurant Beast, as well as Expatriate, a small bar across the street from it - expresses this fear in an interview with \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/05/04/restaurants-some-states-fire-up-again-proprietors-wonder-if-rich-dining-landscape-will-ever-be-same/\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe Washington Post\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cblockquote\u003e\\\"Beast will never exist again. I had two communal tables where you sit right next to people you don’t know. I have to shut off a concept I spent 12 years building, and I don’t know yet what the next thing is going to be.”\u003c/blockquote\u003e\u003cp\u003eSome possibilities facing restaurants in the future are:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eDining room capacity reductions of 50% or more\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eSignificant reduction of bar seating capacity\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eEarly closing hours (e.g., legally enforced last call at 10 p.m.)\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch2\u003eService changes\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cp\u003eThere's also a chance that restaurants' business models will have to fundamentally change. In a world where fewer people can - and want - to sit in a dining room, restaurants \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.pennlive.com/coronavirus/2020/05/what-does-the-future-of-restaurants-look-like-as-pa-eases-guidelines.html\\\"\u003emay\u003c/a\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003ePivot to take out as their primary business\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eTransition to grab-and-go concepts\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eMove to food trucks instead of brick-and-mortar locations\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eCheck customers' temperatures before allowing them to enter\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eDiscourage guests from congregating in bars or lobbies\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eLimit menu options to boost margins\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eWhat do you think?\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eHow do you think restaurants' businesses will change post-pandemic? Will changes need to put in place before you dine out again? Are you planning on returning to business-as-usual? across the U.S. have begun allowing non-essential businesses, including restaurants, to reopen—with\",\"html_byline\":\"\u003cp class='article-byline'\u003eby \u003ca 5.12.20\u003c/p\u003e\",\"share_count\":1,\"reaction_config_id\":null,\"is_countable_article\":false,\"published_at\":\"2020-05-12T17:47:42.600Z\",\"allow_advocacy\":true,\"signed\":false,\"signatures_count\":null,\"signatures_goal\":100,\"signable_progress\":0,\"video_url\":null,\"video_dimensions\":null,\"video_aspect_ratio\":null,\"formatted_publish_date\":\"5.12.20\",\"issue_ids\":[\"health\",\"food-and-agriculture\",\"small-business\",\"jobs\"]},{\"title\":\"Will COVID-19 Affect How You Plan to Vote This November?\",\"id\":44418,\"slug\":\"44418-covid-19-affect-plan-vote-november\",\"links\":{\"self\":\"https://www.causes.com/articles/44418-covid-19-affect-plan-vote-november\",\"article_comments\":\"/api/articles/44418-covid-19-affect-plan-vote-november/comments\",\"signatures\":\"/api/v3/articles/44418/signatures?include=user\"},\"content\":\"\u003ch2\u003eWhat's the story?\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/visualizations/coronavirus-covid-19-spread-map/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe coronavirus outbreak\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u0026nbsp;has disrupted the 2020 election calendar, prompting states to shift their presidential primaries and other votes.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThese changes also include shifts away from the traditional visiting of polling places.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePrimary elections do not have the same rate of turnout as general elections. Still, this primary season might provide insight into how people vote in November’s election\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eChanging primary landscape\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eTuesday, April 28, should have hosted six primaries: Connecticut, Delaware, Maryland, New York, Pennsylvania, and Rhode Island. Instead, the only state that voted was Ohio.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eAfter cancelling its March 17 in-person primary, Ohio conducted its election almost entirely by mail. Gov. Mike DeWine initially proposed June 2 as a substitute, but the Ohio legislature moved the official primary date to April 28. Ballots postmarked by April 27 will be counted.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eNew York state cancelled its presidential primary entirely. Over a dozen other states are weighing how to proceed with their primaries.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eHow states shifted their primaries after the onset of COVID-19\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eAs of April 27, 15 states and territories have either delayed their primaries or switched to a vote-by-mail system with extended deadlines.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/a51771/State1.PNG\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/f25c6d/State2.PNG\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eIt’s difficult to measure COVID-19’s impact on primary turnout\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eComparisons to previous election cycles are always tough; some years had competitive Democratic and Republican races, which brings more people to the polls. In contrast, this year only had a competitive Democratic primary race, which, by early April, had whittled down to former Vice President Joe Biden.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eIt's also worth considering that primary turnout lags far behind the turnout for the general election.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003ePrimary turnout hit a record high in 2008, with 30.4% of all eligible voters heading to the polls. The\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/data/topics/people-society/democracy-and-society/elections/presidential-voting-rate/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003epresidential voting rate\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;for that year, by contrast, was 58.2%.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eKeeping in mind these historical trends, how have states voted during the coronavirus crisis?\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eArizona, Florida, and Illinois\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eOn March 17, just as the coronavirus crisis was beginning to accelerate across the US, Arizona, Florida, and Illinois held their elections as planned.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eIn Arizona, where presidential primaries are closed to party members, the Democratic contest drew 48.8% turnout compared to 37% four years ago.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/f841f6/Arizona1.PNG\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFlorida also has closed primaries. There, 68.2% of the 3 million ballots cast in this year’s presidential primary were mail-in or early votes. In the 2016 presidential primaries—which featured competitive races in both parties—52% of the 4 million ballots were not cast at in-person polling places on Election Day. This year’s presidential primaries drew 30.2% of Florida’s registered voters, while turnout in 2016 was 46.2%.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"data:image/png;base64,\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn Illinois: 28.4% of registered voters cast ballots in the March 17 primary. This is the third-lowest turnout for a presidential primary in the past four decades. However, four of the previous six primaries saw turnouts of less than 30%.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/08592a/Illinois.PNG\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eVoting in the midst of the COVID-19 crisis: Wisconsin\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eWisconsin held its primary–in person–in the midst of the coronavirus outbreak.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAfter moving through state courts to the Supreme Court, Wisconsin voted as scheduled in its presidential primary election on April 7. According to the\u003ca href=\\\"https://elections.wi.gov/blog\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u0026nbsp;Wisconsin Elections Commission\u003c/a\u003e, 34.3% of voters turned out to cast their ballots. While this was smaller than the voter turnout in the spring 2016 election (47%), it was similar to past presidential primaries.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/91b9fe/Wisconsin.PNG\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eIn-person voting on the decline\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eEven before the pandemic, the percentage of votes cast in-person has declined over the decade. The number of states offering early voting, vote-by-mail, and no-excuse absentee voting increased over the past 10 years.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/cfd783/Election.PNG\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eThe total number of US citizens who voted early, absentee, or by mail more than doubled between 2004 and 2016: from 24.9 million in 2004 to 57.2 million in 2016.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eIn 2016, two in five of all ballots were cast remotely.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eThe number of voters casting early ballots more than doubled across the above timeline: from nearly 10.2 million in 2004 to 24.1 million in 2016.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eIn 2016, 16 states had a combined total of greater than 50% of votes cast early, by mail, or via absentee voting.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eYears to prepare\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eThe states that have, in the past, switched to mail-in voting had years to prepare. Wisconsin revealed the difficulty of trying to quickly accommodate remote voting or in-person voting while simultaneously respecting social-distancing guidelines.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eIn recent weeks, the US Election Assistance Commission, a bipartisan and independent federal commission established by the Help America Vote Act of 2002 (HAVA), addressed some of the challenges that COVID-19 may present if still prevalent during November’s general election.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eCosts\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eSending ballots by mail increases printing costs for an election. The Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, signed by President Donald Trump on March 27, includes $400 million in additional Help America Vote Act (HAVA) emergency funds, which will help states prevent, prepare for, and respond to the coronavirus during the 2020 federal election cycle.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003ePoll Workers\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eIf COVID-19 doesn’t abate by the November general election, or states hold in-person primaries like Wisconsin did, another concern is for those working the polls.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eEAC’s 2018 Election Administration and Voting Survey reported that roughly 58% of poll workers during the 2018 midterms were aged 61 or older. This is the same age demographic that may be at an elevated risk for serious complications from COVID-19, according to\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/specific-groups/high-risk-complications.html\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eguidance from the Centers for Disease Control \u0026amp; Prevention.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eAnd it’s not only people working the polls, but those visiting them.\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/data/topics/people-society/democracy-and-society/elections/presidential-voting-rate/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u0026nbsp;Citizens 65 and older are the largest voter bloc.\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;In 2016, for example, 68.4% of all eligible voters over the age of 65 cast a ballot.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eAccurate Voter Data\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eEven states that have adopted remote voting pre-COVID-19 experience issues with undeliverable mailings. Oregon, which has sent ballots to every voter since 1998,\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.cisa.gov/sites/default/files/publications/importance_of_accurate_voter_data_508.pdf\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u0026nbsp;has 2-3% of its ballots\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;returned as undeliverable in federal elections. Washington, which also sends every voter a ballot, has approximately 10% of its ballots returned as undeliverable, according to\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.eac.gov/sites/default/files/electionofficials/vbm/Accurate_Voter_Record_041720.pdf\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u0026nbsp;EAC\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eFederal considerations for state voting\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eWhile the voting process is determined by state and local governments, not the federal government, a national vote-by-mail system is being discussed in Washington, D.C., including by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) and President Trump.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eAccording to a recent report from the\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://crsreports.congress.gov/product/pdf/IF/IF11477\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003enonpartisan Congressional Research Service\u003c/a\u003e, there are a number of bills that would either fund or require states to offer early or mail-based voting.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eWith or without federal action, COVID-19 and its associated social distancing guidelines may play a significant role in November’s voting process. How many people vote—and how they vote—in the remaining primaries may hint at what to expect in the general election.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eSOURCES \u0026amp; FOOTNOTES\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.eac.gov/sites/default/files/eac_assets/1/6/2018_EAVS_Report.pdf\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUS Election Assistance Commission\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u0026nbsp;-\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003e2018 Comprehensive Report\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://elections.il.gov/electionoperations/ElectionResults.aspx\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIllinois State Board of Elections\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://dos.myflorida.com/elections/data-statistics/elections-data/voter-turnout/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFlorida Division of Elections\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://elections.wi.gov/blog\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWisconsin Elections Commission\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://azsos.gov/elections/voter-registration-historical-election-data/historical-election-results-information\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eArizona Secretary of State\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e—Josh Herman\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(Photo Credit: iStock /\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.istockphoto.com/portfolio/m_pavlov?mediatype=illustration\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cem\u003em_pavlov\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\",\"user_id\":824038,\"cta_prompt\":\"\",\"cta_type\":\"share\",\"cta_text\":\"\",\"cta_url\":\"\",\"image_urls\":{\"large\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/d94347/2020Corona.jpg\",\"medium\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/d94347/2020Corona.jpg\",\"small\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/d94347/2020Corona.jpg\",\"thumb\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/d94347/2020Corona.jpg\",\"xsmall\":\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/d94347/2020Corona.jpg\"},\"profile_id\":1527,\"action_count\":4,\"html_content\":\"\u003cp class='article-byline'\u003eby \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.causes.com/cause/public-health-resource-center\\\"\u003eCovid-19 Health Resource Center\u003c/a\u003e | 5.12.20\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch2\u003eWhat's the story?\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\\n\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/visualizations/coronavirus-covid-19-spread-map/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe coronavirus outbreak\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e has disrupted the 2020 election calendar, prompting states to shift their presidential primaries and other votes.\u003c/strong\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThese changes also include shifts away from the traditional visiting of polling places.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePrimary elections do not have the same rate of turnout as general elections. Still, this primary season might provide insight into how people vote in November’s election\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eChanging primary landscape\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eTuesday, April 28, should have hosted six primaries: Connecticut, Delaware, Maryland, New York, Pennsylvania, and Rhode Island. Instead, the only state that voted was Ohio.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eAfter cancelling its March 17 in-person primary, Ohio conducted its election almost entirely by mail. Gov. Mike DeWine initially proposed June 2 as a substitute, but the Ohio legislature moved the official primary date to April 28. Ballots postmarked by April 27 will be counted.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eNew York state cancelled its presidential primary entirely. Over a dozen other states are weighing how to proceed with their primaries.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eHow states shifted their primaries after the onset of COVID-19\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eAs of April 27, 15 states and territories have either delayed their primaries or switched to a vote-by-mail system with extended deadlines.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/a51771/State1.PNG\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/f25c6d/State2.PNG\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eIt’s difficult to measure COVID-19’s impact on primary turnout\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eComparisons to previous election cycles are always tough; some years had competitive Democratic and Republican races, which brings more people to the polls. In contrast, this year only had a competitive Democratic primary race, which, by early April, had whittled down to former Vice President Joe Biden.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eIt's also worth considering that primary turnout lags far behind the turnout for the general election.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003ePrimary turnout hit a record high in 2008, with 30.4% of all eligible voters heading to the polls. The \u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/data/topics/people-society/democracy-and-society/elections/presidential-voting-rate/\\\"\u003epresidential voting rate\u003c/a\u003e for that year, by contrast, was 58.2%.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eKeeping in mind these historical trends, how have states voted during the coronavirus crisis?\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eArizona, Florida, and Illinois\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eOn March 17, just as the coronavirus crisis was beginning to accelerate across the US, Arizona, Florida, and Illinois held their elections as planned.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eIn Arizona, where presidential primaries are closed to party members, the Democratic contest drew 48.8% turnout compared to 37% four years ago.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/f841f6/Arizona1.PNG\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFlorida also has closed primaries. There, 68.2% of the 3 million ballots cast in this year’s presidential primary were mail-in or early votes. In the 2016 presidential primaries—which featured competitive races in both parties—52% of the 4 million ballots were not cast at in-person polling places on Election Day. This year’s presidential primaries drew 30.2% of Florida’s registered voters, while turnout in 2016 was 46.2%.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"data:image/png;base64,\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn Illinois: 28.4% of registered voters cast ballots in the March 17 primary. This is the third-lowest turnout for a presidential primary in the past four decades. However, four of the previous six primaries saw turnouts of less than 30%.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/08592a/Illinois.PNG\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eVoting in the midst of the COVID-19 crisis: Wisconsin\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eWisconsin held its primary–in person–in the midst of the coronavirus outbreak.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAfter moving through state courts to the Supreme Court, Wisconsin voted as scheduled in its presidential primary election on April 7. According to the\u003ca href=\\\"https://elections.wi.gov/blog\\\"\u003e Wisconsin Elections Commission\u003c/a\u003e, 34.3% of voters turned out to cast their ballots. While this was smaller than the voter turnout in the spring 2016 election (47%), it was similar to past presidential primaries.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/91b9fe/Wisconsin.PNG\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eIn-person voting on the decline\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eEven before the pandemic, the percentage of votes cast in-person has declined over the decade. The number of states offering early voting, vote-by-mail, and no-excuse absentee voting increased over the past 10 years.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://ul.countable.us/ul/q_auto/uploads/gZAMg8wZ/cfd783/Election.PNG\\\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eThe total number of US citizens who voted early, absentee, or by mail more than doubled between 2004 and 2016: from 24.9 million in 2004 to 57.2 million in 2016.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eIn 2016, two in five of all ballots were cast remotely.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eThe number of voters casting early ballots more than doubled across the above timeline: from nearly 10.2 million in 2004 to 24.1 million in 2016.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eIn 2016, 16 states had a combined total of greater than 50% of votes cast early, by mail, or via absentee voting.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eYears to prepare\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eThe states that have, in the past, switched to mail-in voting had years to prepare. Wisconsin revealed the difficulty of trying to quickly accommodate remote voting or in-person voting while simultaneously respecting social-distancing guidelines.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eIn recent weeks, the US Election Assistance Commission, a bipartisan and independent federal commission established by the Help America Vote Act of 2002 (HAVA), addressed some of the challenges that COVID-19 may present if still prevalent during November’s general election.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eCosts\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eSending ballots by mail increases printing costs for an election. The Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, signed by President Donald Trump on March 27, includes $400 million in additional Help America Vote Act (HAVA) emergency funds, which will help states prevent, prepare for, and respond to the coronavirus during the 2020 federal election cycle.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003ePoll Workers\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eIf COVID-19 doesn’t abate by the November general election, or states hold in-person primaries like Wisconsin did, another concern is for those working the polls.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eEAC’s 2018 Election Administration and Voting Survey reported that roughly 58% of poll workers during the 2018 midterms were aged 61 or older. This is the same age demographic that may be at an elevated risk for serious complications from COVID-19, according to \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/specific-groups/high-risk-complications.html\\\"\u003eguidance from the Centers for Disease Control \u0026amp; Prevention.\u003c/a\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eAnd it’s not only people working the polls, but those visiting them.\u003ca href=\\\"https://usafacts.org/data/topics/people-society/democracy-and-society/elections/presidential-voting-rate/\\\"\u003e Citizens 65 and older are the largest voter bloc.\u003c/a\u003e In 2016, for example, 68.4% of all eligible voters over the age of 65 cast a ballot.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eAccurate Voter Data\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eEven states that have adopted remote voting pre-COVID-19 experience issues with undeliverable mailings. Oregon, which has sent ballots to every voter since 1998,\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.cisa.gov/sites/default/files/publications/importance_of_accurate_voter_data_508.pdf\\\"\u003e has 2-3% of its ballots\u003c/a\u003e returned as undeliverable in federal elections. Washington, which also sends every voter a ballot, has approximately 10% of its ballots returned as undeliverable, according to\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.eac.gov/sites/default/files/electionofficials/vbm/Accurate_Voter_Record_041720.pdf\\\"\u003e EAC\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eFederal considerations for state voting\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eWhile the voting process is determined by state and local governments, not the federal government, a national vote-by-mail system is being discussed in Washington, D.C., including by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) and President Trump.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eAccording to a recent report from the \u003ca href=\\\"https://crsreports.congress.gov/product/pdf/IF/IF11477\\\"\u003enonpartisan Congressional Research Service\u003c/a\u003e, there are a number of bills that would either fund or require states to offer early or mail-based voting.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eWith or without federal action, COVID-19 and its associated social distancing guidelines may play a significant role in November’s voting process. How many people vote—and how they vote—in the remaining primaries may hint at what to expect in the general election.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3\u003eSOURCES \u0026amp; FOOTNOTES\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\\n\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.eac.gov/sites/default/files/eac_assets/1/6/2018_EAVS_Report.pdf\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUS Election Assistance Commission\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e - \u003c/strong\u003e2018 Comprehensive Report\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://elections.il.gov/electionoperations/ElectionResults.aspx\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIllinois State Board of Elections\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://dos.myflorida.com/elections/data-statistics/elections-data/voter-turnout/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFlorida Division of Elections\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://elections.wi.gov/blog\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWisconsin Elections Commission\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca
